Since the hospital was opened 1 year ago, the hospital management has received several reports of physicians inadvertently overlooking important clinical information in patient records, clinical deterioration of admitted patients following missed changes in vital signs, laboratory test results being issued for wrong patients, and patients accidentally receiving incorrect drug doses. An insurance company had also recently accused the hospital of billing for services that were never performed. A root cause analysis is most likely to reveal which of the following as the common source of the errors that occurred at the hospital?

choices.text: Blame culture at the workplace
Copy functionality in documentation
Misconduct by a hospital administrator
Medical knowledge deficits among frontline staff
Value-based care reimbursement model

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blame culture refers to a situation in which health care employees are reluctant to report errors due to fear of prosecution or criticism. In this case, the physician openly disclosed the error to the patient and via the hospital's event reporting system, so there is no evidence of blame culture or a lack of psychological safety at the hospital.

B) CORRECT:

Documentation errors caused by copying and pasting information in electronic health records (EHRs) are the most likely common source of the medical errors described here. EHRs, which were increasingly adopted following the HITECH Act of 2009, have several advantages (e.g., transparency, high fidelity) but also create the possibility for certain errors. The copy/paste function may result in the entry of incorrect or outdated information or the entry of information into the wrong patient's EHR, and subsequently lead to errors such as incorrect drug dosing, performing tests or treatment on the wrong patient, and billing for services that were never performed. Duplicating information also promotes note bloat, the proliferation of lengthy notes that include redundant, nonessential information, which may lead to physicians overlooking important facts. The unchecked transfer of outdated patient data, such as previous vital signs, can lead to the deterioration of patients due to missed changes in their condition.

Forcing functions on workstations such as allowing only one EHR to be open at a time, clipboard clearing, and disabling copy/paste functionality in certain parts of the EHR can prevent these errors. Other measures to improve safety with EHR use include the implementation of standardized protocols (e.g., SAFER guide) and personnel training.

C) INCORRECT:

Misconduct by a hospital administrator (e.g., the hospital's accountant) could explain the insurance company's accusations of potential insurance fraud. However, the multiple adverse events described here were most likely made by multiple staff members (i.e., physicians, nurses) and therefore can not be attributed to a single hospital administrator.

D) INCORRECT:

Medical knowledge deficits among health care providers (HCPs) can lead to nescient errors in diagnosis and treatment, in which HCPs overlook relevant symptoms and examination findings. However, incorrect dose prescriptions and patient misidentification by HCPs are more likely to be caused by slips and lapses (types of skill-based error) than by nescient errors.

E) INCORRECT:

Value-based care (i.e. pay for performance) is a payment model in which compensation depends on health care providers meeting certain metrics for the quality and efficiency of care provided. This payment model typically promotes coordination and quality of care through financial incentives, which is why it is unlikely to be responsible for the multiple adverse events at this organization. Fee-for-service reimbursement models, on the other hand, typically lead to healthcare fragmentation and may thereby increase the incidence of medical errors and lead to unnecessary repetition of services.
questions.hint: All the medical errors described here are related to a particular workaround in one of the hospital's management systems.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, carotid artery stenosis, vascular dementia, and recurrent episodes of transient visual loss is admitted to the hospital for carotid endarterectomy. Duplex ultrasonography and CT angiography of the carotid arteries had shown an 80% stenosis on the right and 50% stenosis on the left. A shared decision to perform right-sided carotid endarterectomy was made with consent from the patient's medical power of attorney, and the management plan was documented in the patient records as CEA right. The surgical intern meets the patient on the ward on the day of surgery and, using a permanent marker, circles the surgical site and marks X on the nonsurgical site. The patient is brought to the operating room and the circulating nurse confirms that all relevant patient documents and findings are available. While the surgical team is scrubbing, the anesthetist asks the patient to verify her surgery site by pointing to it. Regional anesthesia is performed, and the patient is draped. The surgery is subsequently performed without any complications. While filling out the signout checklist after the surgery, the circulating nurse notices that the surgery was performed on the left carotid artery instead of the right. Which of the following actions would most likely have prevented this never event?

choices.text: Performing surgical site marking in the operating room
Providing the patient with a radiofrequency identification wrist band
Avoiding the use of abbreviations in patient records
Conducting a time-out immediately prior to surgery
Using adhesive tape for surgical site marking

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

It is generally recommended that surgical site marking be performed in the preoperative area, where there are fewer distractions compared to the operating room. Marking may be performed by the attending surgeon after verbal confirmation from the patient, although it is acceptable to delegate to another person who will also be present during the procedure (e.g., the surgical intern in this scenario), or by the patient directly in front of the surgeon, but the site marking protocol should be standardized for each institution.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiofrequency identification wrist bands can be used to verify a patient's identity and prevent errors caused by patient misidentification (e.g., wrong patient surgery). However, they are not typically used to identify surgical sites and it is unlikely that they would have prevented this patient's wrong-site surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

The use of nonstandardized abbreviations in documentation should be avoided to minimize errors. However, in this scenario, the procedure was documented as CEA right and correctly identified the laterality of the procedure.

D) CORRECT:

The Universal Protocol is a three-step process:

1. preprocedural verification of the patient's identity, the surgical site, and the surgical procedure;
2. surgical site marking;
3. performing a time-out.

A surgical time-out is performed in the operating room prior to the procedure to reconfirm the patient's identity, the procedure, and the surgical site. The time-out is typically initiated by a designated member of the team, such as the circulating nurse, and involves all of the team members (e.g., operating room technicians, principal surgeon, medical students) who are participating in the procedure. The whole team is responsible for reviewing all of the relevant information through active communication, and once everyone is in agreement, the time-out should be documented. A successful time-out requires a safety culture, which provides an environment in which health care providers can actively speak up about potential errors.

The protocol for surgical site marking was also not followed correctly in this scenario. When marking the surgical site, the correct site should be marked by writing the word YES, the surgeon's initials, or both using an indelible marker. The incorrect surgical site should not be marked; this includes marking with the word NO or an ambiguous visual cue (e.g., an X could also be interpreted as an indicator of the correct site).

E) INCORRECT:

The Joint Commission recommends making permanent surgical site markings to ensure that they are still visible following surgical preparation (e.g., antiseptic skin preparation and draping). Therefore, adhesive tape is not recommended because it can easily be rubbed off or transferred to a different site, which can result in wrong-site surgery.
questions.hint: The Universal Protocol should be followed to prevent never events such as wrong-site surgery. This protocol consists of a series of steps based on the human factors engineering strategy of redundancy and standardization and should be performed before invasive medical procedures. In this scenario, the surgeon did not follow the protocol for one of these steps correctly and a subsequent step was missed entirely. If this subsequent step had been performed, it could have reduced the likelihood of the error occurring by acting as an additional safety measure (i.e., a Swiss cheese model).

questions.text: The event reporting system of a hospital logs three incidents of electrothermal injury to patients during surgical procedures over a 1-week period. The surgical team notices that these adverse events began shortly after the introduction of new electrocautery devices in the operating rooms. The new devices are a different brand than the ones used previously and were procured by the hospital management using a transparent tendering process as a replacement for some of the old electrocautery devices that had started to malfunction. The staff have been using electrocautery devices for a long time and did not report any incidents of electrothermal injuries with the old brand of electrocautery devices. A root cause analysis reveals that adverse events primarily occurred because the alarms of the new devices were too loud and distracting, and the surgical staff would occasionally turn down the alarm volume. Implementation of which of the following measures before introducing the new electrocautery device in the operating rooms would most likely have prevented the electrothermal injuries?

choices.text: Installing sound insulation in the operating room and replacing noisy surgical equipment with quieter ones
Placing signs on the new devices that warn staff not to switch off the alarm during surgeries
Providing a demonstration for the surgical staff on correct usage of the new devices
Purchasing new device models of the same brand when old device models need to be replaced
Testing the new devices in the operating rooms using simulated surgeries

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

High levels of noise in operating rooms are a distraction and have been proven to facilitate medical errors. The elimination of distraction is considered an intermediate-level action in preventing medical errors according to the action hierarchy of HFE. However, general noise reduction would not have prevented the adverse effects in this case, since the alarm signals of the electrocautery device could still have been turned down even if the general noise level was already decreased.

B) INCORRECT:

Placing warning signs on new devices is an example of visual warning cues, which can prevent medical errors. However, error prevention strategies such as warnings, double checks, training, and the introduction of new policies (e.g., checking the alarm volume hourly) are considered weaker actions according to the action hierarchy of HFE, because they rely strongly on human effort for error mitigation.

C) INCORRECT:

Providing demonstrations of new devices is an example of training, which can prevent medical errors. However, error prevention strategies such as training, double checks, warnings, and the introduction of new policies (e.g., checking the alarm volume hourly) are considered weaker actions according to the action hierarchy of HFE, because they rely strongly on human effort for error mitigation.

D) INCORRECT:

Equipment standardization (e.g., ensuring that all electrocautery devices in the operating room are of the same brand as well as the model) is a stronger action in the action hierarchy of HFE. However, purchasing new models of the same brand as a replacement for malfunctioning old device models is not an example of standardization since new devices from the same brand may have new features that hospital staff are unaware of. A different strategy is required to prevent errors when devices of a different model or brand are purchased.

E) CORRECT:

Testing new devices before implementation (usability testing) under simulated or actual conditions can help identify unanticipated risks that may result in workarounds, which may lead to medical errors. New devices can be evaluated based on whether they meet the users' requirements (design validation) regarding the intended purpose and usability. In the action hierarchy of HFE, this method of error prevention is considered a stronger action, meaning that it is more effective in preventing medical errors since it does not rely on human effort for error mitigation compared to weaker actions such as training, double checks, warnings, and the introduction of new policies (e.g., checking the alarm volume hourly). Another example of a stronger action is the implementation of a forcing function, e.g., a design feature that switches off the electrocautery device if the volume falls below a certain level.
questions.hint: The adverse event in this scenario (electrothermal injury) was the result of a workaround. When humans interact with medical equipment, various types of errors can occur: human errors, device errors, or errors at the level of the device-human interface. Some human factors engineering strategies  (HFE strategies) are more effective than others at preventing medical errors.

questions.text: The chief medical officer at an obstetrics and gynecology clinic has noticed an increased refusal rate for the human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine among teenage girls over the past 6 months. The chief medical officer meets with all physicians who provide vaccination counseling and performs mock consultations for training. In response to a simulated patient query about the risk of syncope from the quadrivalent HPV vaccine, an attending physician who has experienced very low rates of vaccination refusal says, More than 99.99% of patients who received the quadrivalent vaccine did not report any adverse effects and only 0.008% of patients who received the quadrivalent vaccine had significant lightheadedness. In response to the same query, an intern who has experienced comparatively higher rates of vaccination refusal says, Approximately 50 in 100,000 patients who receive the quadrivalent vaccine report at least one adverse effect, and approximately 15% of those who reported an adverse effect had significant lightheadedness as one of the adverse effects. When compared to the attending physician's response, which of the following types of cognitive bias is most likely to affect a patient who hears the intern's response?

choices.text: Framing
Anchoring
Visceral
Confirmation
Availability

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Framing bias is the tendency for an individual's conclusions to be unduly influenced by the way information is presented (framed). The framing bias in this scenario is the result of a heuristic that makes people prefer an option when its positive aspects (positive frame) are highlighted and its negative ones (negative frame) are minimized (e.g., "glass half full" vs. glass half empty). The consequences of framing biases should be considered during patient counseling and when formulating public health messages. When using a shared decision-making strategy, the effects of framing bias can be minimized by providing both the positive and negative frames, and by using patient decision aids.

Cognitive biases can also affect health care providers. For example, the phrasing or order of presentation of information in electronic health records or during patient handovers and patient interviews can emphasize one aspect of the patient's health information over another aspect and lead to diagnostic errors as a result of a framing bias.

B) INCORRECT:

Anchoring bias is the tendency for an individual to stick ("anchor") to a prior conclusion even when new information that goes against this conclusion is presented. An example of an anchoring bias is a situation in which a patient who believes that HPV vaccination is harmful does not change their mind even when the physician presents information supporting the safety and efficacy of HPV vaccination.

C) INCORRECT:

Visceral bias refers to a tendency to allow positive or negative feelings to influence decision-making. An example of visceral bias would be a situation in which a patient refuses HPV vaccination because the patient mistrusts the physician as a result of transference.

D) INCORRECT:

Confirmation bias is the tendency for an individual to selectively seek and emphasize information that supports their prior conclusion and overlook information that goes against the conclusion. An example of confirmation bias is a situation in which a patient who already believes that HPV vaccination is harmful selectively reads up on adverse events following HPV vaccination.

E) INCORRECT:

Availability bias is the tendency to consider past events perceived as significant or readily recalled information as more representative of the truth than events perceived as insignificant or information that comes to mind less promptly. An example of availability bias would be a situation in which a patient refuses HPV vaccination after hearing about a friend who experiences syncope following HPV vaccination and fails to consider all the individuals who have not experienced any adverse event after HPV vaccination.
questions.hint: Both the attending physician and the intern present the same information. However, the intern's phrasing of the response, which focuses more on the vaccine's negative outcomes, might influence patients' decision-making process and lead to vaccination refusal.

questions.text: The head of a large university hospital notices that the likelihood of a patient dying from acute coronary syndrome (ACS) depends on their time of arrival to the emergency department (ED). The time required to activate the catheterization laboratory (cath lab) is shorter for ED shifts with multiple on-call attending physicians when compared to shifts with a single on-call attending physician. In the ED, the resident who sees a patient with suspected ACS has to consult an attending physician, who ultimately determines whether percutaneous coronary intervention is required. The services of the cath lab can only be activated by authorization of the attending physician after electronic verification of the attending physician's identity. This policy was implemented a year ago by the ED head after the cardiology department complained of futile cath lab activations. After discussions with a multidisciplinary team, a simplified clinical decision support rule for cath lab activation is implemented to make up for a staffing shortfall. All ED physicians, including residents, are trained to use this decision rule and permitted to independently activate the cath lab. These interventions are most likely to have which of the following effects at the hospital?

choices.text: Decreased variance of door-to-balloon time
Increased lockout period for cath lab activation
Increased case fatality rate of ACS patients
Decreased net workload capacity of ED personnel
Decreased situational awareness scores among ED physicians

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Door-to-balloon-time (D2B time) is a process measure. Standardization increases the reliability of a process and thereby decreases the magnitude of dispersion of process measures (e.g., variance of D2B time) as well as outcome measures (e.g., variance of case fatality rate). The new policy furthermore implies removal of a forcing function and introduction of training and cognitive aids, which decrease the process measure's central tendency (e.g., mean D2B time) and thereby the magnitude of the outcome measure's central tendency (e.g., mean case fatality rate of ACS).

This scenario also highlights the importance of a systems-based approach to quality improvement (QI) and the need for process validation when implementing a QI strategy in one aspect of a system, e.g., through change impact analysis, failure mode and effects analysis, or checking balancing measures. The forcing function was implemented in the ED at the request of the cardiology department before considering the effect of staffing shortfalls in the ED. It was not considered that a forcing function can prevent the timely performance of a critical step (e.g., cath lab activation) and can cause the entire process (e.g., chain of survival) to fail.

B) INCORRECT:

The lockout period is the duration for which a forcing function (a type of HFE strategy) prevents an event from happening. The new hospital policy removes a forcing function (disallowing residents from activating the cath lab), so the lockout period for cath lab activation decreases to zero rather than increases.

C) INCORRECT:

Two of the most important determinants of case fatality rates of out-of-hospital ACS are the onset-to-door time and the time to initiation of reperfusion therapy; the expertise of the person who activates the cath lab is irrelevant. The new policy implemented by the hospital would be expected to decrease the case fatality rate of admitted ACS patients by removing any bottlenecks in cath lab activation, and to decrease the ED wait time of patients with ACS.

D) INCORRECT:

Workload capacity is the amount of cognitive processing power that is available to perform a task. The interventions at the hospital implement a cognitive aid to assist residents and attending physicians in decision-making; cognitive aids decrease the mental workload and increase workload capacity. The intervention further increases the workload capacity of attending physicians by decentralizing decision-making responsibility. Therefore, the interventions would be expected to increase, not decrease, the net workload capacity of ED personnel.

E) INCORRECT:

Situational awareness is an individual's perception of their environment, understanding of its meaning, and ability to predict its possible implications for the future. Any form of personnel training, which was one of the hospital's interventions, would be expected to increase, not decrease, situational awareness and scores on standardized tests for situational awareness.
questions.hint: Through the new policy, which allows all ED physicians to independently activate the cath lab based on a determined set of rules without the need for a consult, the hospital has replaced a forcing function, a human factors engineering strategy (HFE strategy), with a combination of three other HFE strategies: standardization, training, and cognitive aid. Standardization increases the reliability of a process.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman is hospitalized for the treatment of pneumonia by the end of the inpatient staff's morning shift after a routine admission procedure. She has hypercholesterolemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include simvastatin and insulin. The physician covering the morning shift orders antibiotics and the patient's current medications, all of which are prepared in the hospital pharmacy as ready-to-use single doses in medication dispensers with barcode stickers. After receiving a standardized handoff in a designated distraction-free zone from the team covering the morning shift, the nurse covering the subsequent shift enters the patient's room with a workstation on wheels and the patient's medication dispensers. He introduces himself to the patient. The patient introduces herself with her surname and starts to converse with the nurse. During the conversation, the nurse notices that the patient's issued armband with a patient barcode and identification number is by the bedside on the nightstand. In addition to verifying the type, route, timing, and dose of the medications, which of the following is the most appropriate action by the nurse before administering the medications?

choices.text: Scan the barcodes on the patient's armband and the medication dispensers
Ask the patient to state her full name and date of birth
Request that the patient name and visually identify her chronic disease medications
Check the patient's room number and patient identification number against the inpatient ward logs
Telephone the nurse who covered the previous shift

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While verifying that the barcodes on the patient's armband and the medication dispensers match ensures that the prepared medication is intended for the owner of the armband, it is not an appropriate method of patient identification. An armband is not itself a patient identifier but rather a medium on which unique identifiers (e.g., an identification number) can be printed. Moreover, when an armband is used as part of identification, it must be attached to the patient at all times.

B) CORRECT:

Asking the patient to state their full name and date of birth is a reliable method for verifying their identity prior to a medical intervention (e.g., drawing blood, administering medications or blood products). Further appropriate patient identifiers include an assigned identification number (on an armband attached to the patient), telephone number, or other unique identifiers available in the patient's health record or established on admission. The specific two patient identifiers used for verification should ideally be standardized within a given setting (e.g., consistently using full name and date of birth on this patient's ward).

C) INCORRECT:

Requesting that patients name their chronic disease medications can serve as a safety check when handing out drugs. However, errors are likely to occur when patients are asked to visually identify medications (e.g., due to differences between pharmaceutical brands). Moreover, this nurse is about to administer insulin, a high-alert medication that requires special attention to ensure the correct patient is receiving it.

D) INCORRECT:

While a patient identification number on an armband is considered a unique patient identifier, it loses this quality when the armband is not attached to the patient at all times, as is the case here. A room number is not an appropriate identifier, given that rooms are typically shared and patients are often moved from room to room.

E) INCORRECT:

Asking the nurse who covered the previous shift to verify the patient's identity over the phone is an unreliable method of patient identification. Moreover, it is not appropriate to call a health care provider who is not on duty if not absolutely necessary, as this can contribute to work exhaustion and burnout.
questions.hint: To prevent patient identification errors, the Joint Commission recommends using two patient identifiers prior to any medical intervention.

questions.text: The head of a surgical department at a university hospital notices that the rate of near misses related to the patient identification process prior to surgery has increased over the past year. She decides to implement a monthly recurring meeting in which selected cases are presented and discussed. The aim of the meetings is to identify the individual actions that led to errors by providing a nonpunitive space for self-reflection, and to determine strategies to prevent their recurrence. Both surgeons and surgical trainees, including residents and students, are asked to attend the meeting. Which of the following is the most accurate description of the activity initiated by the head of the surgical department?

choices.text: Root cause analysis
Lean process improvement
Plan-do-study-act cycle
Morbidity and mortality review
Failure mode and effects analysis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A root cause analysis (RCA) is a type of retrospective patient safety investigation. RCAs can be conducted following the near miss of a sentinel event (e.g., surgery on the wrong patient) and involve interviewing frontline workers (e.g., surgeons). Unlike the meeting described here, however, RCAs focus on identifying problems within systems and processes (blunt-end errors) rather than only individual actions (sharp-end errors) and involve discussions with interprofessional teams (i.e., all staff in the operating room including nurses, technicians, and anesthetists, not just surgeons). In addition, an RCA is a more thorough process than the one described in this scenario; it analyzes all events rather than select cases (if the RCA is conducted after multiple events) and is performed with the 5WH1 and 5 Whys technique and analysis tools (e.g., fishbone diagram) in order to determine the root cause of the problem.

B) INCORRECT:

Lean process improvement in health care means continuously evaluating the efficiency of working processes in order to identify areas of waste and eliminate factors that use time, energy, and resources without improving patient outcomes (e.g., unnecessary diagnostic tests, storage costs for superfluous equipment). While ongoing process improvement helps to prevent medical errors, the aim of the implemented meetings described here is to present and discuss errors that have already occurred.

C) INCORRECT:

The plan-do-study-act (PDSA) cycle is a model that is often used in health care quality management and is typically focused on the rapid as well as continuous development and testing of process changes. The first phase (plan) of the PDSA cycle consists of preparing a new process or tool (e.g., a patient safety training program for surgeons), identifying one or more quality improvement measures (QI measures) that reflect the performance of the new process or tool (e.g., an outcome measure such as the number of near miss events), and establishing a target for a change in the identified QI measure (e.g., a statistically significant decrease in the number of near misses). The implemented meetings described here may be used to assess the need for improvement in specific areas and prepare a plan but do not meet all of the criteria for the first phase of the PDSA cycle.

D) CORRECT:

Morbidity and mortality reviews (M&Ms) are department meetings in which selected cases involving medical errors (including near misses and preventable or ameliorable adverse events) are confidentially presented, reviewed, and discussed among peers. The meetings should ideally follow a standardized format that includes analyzing medical errors and determining improvement measures to be followed up. M&Ms take place at regular intervals, typically monthly. The goal of an M&M is not to punish individuals but to identify measures for individual improvement and increase situational awareness as well as collective responsibility among team members. Since M&Ms are a type of peer review activity, the meeting's proceedings, findings, and recommendations (as well as any documentation) are legally protected and inadmissible in malpractice lawsuits.

E) INCORRECT:

Failure mode and effects analysis is a prospective error analysis that is used to identify potential risks and hazards and take preventive measures before a medical error occurs. Components of this analysis include the identification of what could go wrong (failure mode), identification of why it could go wrong (failure causes), identification of the outcomes of the potential failures (failure effects), and proactive implementation of corrective measures. The aim of the implemented meetings described here, however, is to present and discuss errors that have already occurred.
questions.hint: The meeting implemented by the head of the department allows for a retrospective error analysis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department two hours after an episode of shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. He did not cough blood during this episode. His symptoms resolved spontaneously after 15 minutes. He has no history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Medical history is significant for tobacco use disorder and panic disorder, for which the patient takes sertraline. He appears anxious. Pulse is 88/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99% on room air. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is no leg asymmetry or edema. ECG is normal. The emergency room physician determines that the patient has a very low probability of having a pulmonary embolism, but decides to order a serum D-dimer test to evaluate for pulmonary embolism. The physician's decision was most likely subject to which of the following types of bias?

choices.text: Availability bias
Visceral bias
Confirmation bias
Gender bias
Commission bias

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Availability bias is the tendency to consider past events perceived as significant or readily recalled information as more representative of the truth than events perceived as insignificant or information that comes to mind less promptly. An example of availability bias would be a situation in which the physician orders serum D-dimer testing to rule out pulmonary embolism (PE) because he recently missed a diagnosis of PE in a different patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Visceral bias is the tendency for clinical decisions to be influenced by positive or negative feelings towards the patient. An example of visceral bias would be a situation in which the physician doubts the symptoms described by a patient with substance use disorder. There are no indications that the emergency room physician has any positive or negative feelings towards this man.

C) INCORRECT:

Confirmation bias (psychology) is the tendency to favor evidence that supports preconceived notions, ignoring other results. This physician ordered a D-dimer test to evaluate for pulmonary embolism (PE). There is no indication that he has preconceived expectations of PE and is now collecting evidence to confirm the diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Gender bias occurs when assumptions about an individual are incorrectly based on the individual's real or perceived gender. This physician based the decision for D-dimer on the patient's presenting symptoms and concern about having a lung condition. There is no indication that the patient's gender had a significant influence on the physician's decision.

E) CORRECT:

Commission bias is favoring action (e.g., ordering a D-dimer test) over inaction when inaction will likely lead to the same or a better outcome. This patient most likely has had a panic attack. His Wells score for pulmonary embolism (PE) indicates a low probability for PE and the pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (total score of 0 points) indicate that no further diagnostic testing is needed. Regardless of these facts, the physician has ordered a D-dimer test most likely as a result of a sense of obligation to the principle of beneficence.

Commission bias is less common in health care than omission bias, which is the tendency to prefer inaction over action.
questions.hint: This patient's history of panic disorder and 15-minute episode of shortness of breath, chest pain, palpitations, and sweating indicates a panic attack.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man who is being treated in the hospital for new-onset congestive heart failure alerts his nurse because he is feeling unwell. He reports feeling dizzy and nauseous and that he had to lie down again after trying to stand up to go to the bathroom. He says that his symptoms began 30 minutes after he was brought back to the ward from the radiology department, where he underwent a CT scan of the chest to evaluate an incidental pulmonary nodule found on chest x-ray. Medical history is remarkable for coronary artery disease and hypertension. After admission, bisoprolol therapy was temporarily discontinued and he was started on furosemide. His other medications are aspirin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin. The physician on call takes the patients vital signs and measures a pulse of 138/min and blood pressure of 95/70 mm Hg. Further investigation reveals that the changes in the patient's pulse and blood pressure were not detected despite continuous cardiac telemetry being a part of the patient's admission orders. Which of the following is the most likely cause for the error that occurred in this scenario?

choices.text: Failure at the patient-telemetry device interface
Poor communication of telemetry events
Desensitization to alarms from the telemetry device
Malfunctioning of the telemetry device

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

When humans interact with medical equipment, three types of errors occur: human errors, device errors, and errors at the level of the device-human interface. Failure at the level of the device-human interface (e.g., disconnection of the patient from or improper connection of the patient to the telemetry device) is the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors (approx. 50% of cases) and typically occurs after patients are shifted (e.g., for a test). Less common causes of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors are equipment malfunction (25%), communication breakdown (20%), and alarm fatigue (5%). Cardiac telemetry-related errors rarely cause patients to be harmed, but when they do, the consequences are dire with death as the most frequent outcome. Measures that can be taken to prevent such errors include checklists and standardization for inpatient transfers, regular telemetry equipment checks, forcing functions that prevent alarms from being turned down, and redirection of low-level alarms to telemetry technicians to prevent alarm fatigue in nurses.

B) INCORRECT:

Poor communication between healthcare providers about cardiac telemetry events (e.g., when nurses or telemetry technicians fail to notify physicians about alarms) can lead to adequate care being delayed or not initiated at all after an event has been detected. However, poor communication is not the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors. A different cause is much more likely in this scenario, in which the cardiac event occurred soon after the patient returned to the ward.

C) INCORRECT:

Desensitization of health care providers to alarms from the telemetry device (i.e., alarm fatigue) can lead to cardiac events going undetected but is an uncommon cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors.

D) INCORRECT:

Malfunctioning of the cardiac telemetry device (e.g., due to empty batteries in the case of a portable device) can lead to cardiac events going undetected but is not the most common cause of inpatient cardiac telemetry-related errors. A different cause is much more likely in this scenario, in which the cardiac event occurred soon after the patient returned to the ward.
questions.hint: Cardiac telemetry can interfere with the image quality of chest CT scans by causing a beam hardening artifact.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of severe chest pain that began after he lifted a heavy box 1 hour ago. On several previous visits, the physician has diagnosed him with costochondritis. He also has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications are ramipril and metformin. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is mild tenderness to palpation of the 4th to 6th left rib cartilage. The physician diagnoses costochondritis, prescribes ibuprofen, and sends the patient home. Two hours later, the patient is brought to the emergency department with chest pain radiating to the left shoulder, dyspnea, and nausea. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in leads V1 through V4. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this medical error?

choices.text: Commission bias
Conjunction fallacy
Zebra retreat
Information bias
Premature closure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Commission bias is a cognitive bias in which the physician chooses action or intervention when inaction would have resulted in a similar or better outcome (e.g., excessive testing in a low-risk patient). In this scenario, the physician chose inaction (no further testing) over action (performing an ECG). This is an example of omission bias rather than commission bias. There is another term that better describes the main cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

Conjunction fallacy is a logical error in which the probability of multiple coinciding events (e.g., diagnoses) is assumed to be higher than the probability of a single event. The physician in this scenario assumed that the patient was more likely to have one condition (costochondritis) than multiple conditions (costochondritis and myocardial infarction), so conjunction fallacy does not apply. The physician made an immediate diagnosis without considering alternative diagnoses. The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

C) INCORRECT:

Zebra retreat bias is a cognitive bias in which a physician is reluctant to consider a rare diagnosis even though there is evidence that supports the diagnosis. Myocardial infarction is a common condition that should be considered in all patients with chest pain and risk factors for cardiovascular disease. The physician in this scenario made an immediate diagnosis (costochondritis) while failing to consider a common alternative diagnosis (myocardial infarction). The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

D) INCORRECT:

Information bias (psychology) is the tendency to seek more information (e.g., in support of a diagnosis) than is necessary or relevant for making a decision. In this scenario, the physician made a diagnosis (costochondritis) without further verification. The cause of the diagnostic error in this scenario is best described by a different term.

E) CORRECT:

Premature closure bias is a cognitive bias in which a physician makes a premature diagnosis without further verification, thereby increasing the risk of diagnostic errors such as misdiagnosis and delayed diagnosis. In this scenario, the physician immediately made a diagnosis (costochondritis) and failed to consider an alternative cause for the patients chest pain (myocardial infarction). The physician should have taken the patients risk factors for cardiovascular disease (i.e., older age, diabetes mellitus, hypertension) into account and performed further diagnostic testing. An electrocardiogram is indicated for patients > 35 years of age with suspected costochondritis. If the physician had been aware of his cognitive bias, myocardial infarction could have been diagnosed at the office, which may have improved the patient's outcome. Strategies to avoid cognitive biases include education on cognitive errors, diagnostic time-outs, differential diagnosis generators, and checklists.

In many situations, several cognitive errors can occur simultaneously. Omission bias, overconfidence, and availability bias may have also occurred in this scenario.
questions.hint: The physician failed to consider alternative diagnoses (e.g., myocardial infarction) for this patient's chest pain.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is referred to a radiology practice by his primary care physician for a CT scan because of a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea, cough, and hemoptysis. The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years but quit 3 years ago. The CT scan shows a 3-cm nodule with irregular borders in the right upper lobe suggestive of malignancy. The radiologist who reviewed the CT scan writes the final report and uploads it to the patient's electronic health record. Because some of the front office staff in the primary care physician's practice had been out on sick leave, the patient's follow-up visit was rescheduled to 4 weeks later. When the physician finally discusses the results with the patient, the patient becomes angry and says, I have been unable to sleep for the past month because I was so worried about the results, and now I will die because I didn't receive treatment in time. Which of the following strategies would have been most effective in preventing the delay in further management?

choices.text: Computerized alert notifications for the primary care physician upon uploading of the radiology report
Explanation of the imaging findings to the patient by the radiologist in person
Sending concrete follow-up recommendations and a compact disc of the images to the primary care physician via registered mail
Verbal communication of imaging results between the providers via phone
Asking the patient to contact the primary care physician's practice weekly until the imaging results are available

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alert notifications can help physicians receive critical results in a timely manner. However, because physicians often receive an increased amount of notifications, they may not read all alerts and fail to acknowledge critical results (alert fatigue).

B) INCORRECT:

The radiologist may explain critical findings to a patient if the referring physician cannot be contacted in a timely manner or if management will be affected because of delays. However, because the referring physician will provide further management and has also likely built a trusting relationship with the patient, critical test results should be communicated by them whenever possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Follow-up recommendations (e.g., additional diagnostic studies) by the interpreting physician can help the referring physician plan further management. However, mailing records is not the fastest or most efficient method and would not have prevented delays in management. In general, electronic communication of critical imaging results is preferred over paper-based reporting.

D) CORRECT:

In addition to the electronically sent report, critical imaging results should be delivered through additional means of communication that ensure timely receipt of the findings. Verbal communication between providers, either in person or via phone, is recommended as it allows the receiving physician to acknowledge receipt of the information, facilitates further discussion, and is likely to prompt timely follow-up actions. Any additional communication between providers should be properly documented (e.g., method of communication, name of the person who received the information).

Patients should be informed about the manner and time in which they can expect test results to be communicated to them, and should also be made aware of what to do if they do not receive the results in the expected time frame.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients should be informed about the manner and time in which they can expect test results to be communicated to them, and should also be made aware of what to do if they do not receive the results in the expected time frame. However, telling a patient to contact the primary care physician's practice weekly places all responsibility for follow-up on the patient. The referring physician is responsible for obtaining the results of the tests ordered and communicating them with the patient in a timely manner.
questions.hint: To ensure the quality of care and avoid patient harm, critical imaging results should be communicated with the referring physician in a timely manner.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman is evaluated in the rehabilitation facility of a hospital 2 weeks after admission for an ischemic stroke that resulted in right hemiparesis. She has been recovering well. She can walk with the aid of a walker, has no speech impairment, and tolerates a regular diet. Medical history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Medications are metformin, lisinopril, simvastatin, and daily aspirin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Cranial nerves are intact. Muscle strength in the extremities is 5/5 on the left and 3/5 on the right. Sensation is intact bilaterally. Standardized assessment of cognitive function shows mild impairment. The patient says that she is tired of being in the hospital. She lives alone in a small apartment on the ground floor with no stairs. The patient's daughter agrees to take care of her mother but mentions that she cannot afford to take any more time off work. The daughter works part-time as a kindergarten teacher. Which of the following is the most appropriate action to ensure the patient's well-being?

choices.text: Do not discharge the patient
Transfer responsibility for discharge planning to the patient's daughter
Discharge the patient to an assisted living facility
Discuss a plan for regular outpatient visits with the patient
Involve a social worker in discharge planning

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prolonged hospitalization can raise certain risks (e.g., hospital-acquired infections) in older patients and disrupt others' access to care. In addition, physicians should be mindful of the impact on health care resources (e.g., staffing, health care costs). This patient is medically stable and should not be kept at the hospital any longer than necessary.

B) INCORRECT:

The physician should involve the patient's family and future caregivers in discharge planning and identify who will be primarily responsible for understanding the discharge instructions. However, physicians, together with other health care personnel, are obligated to ensure safe discharge planning, and this responsibility cannot be transferred to a family member.

C) INCORRECT:

An inpatient program (e.g., assisted living facilities) may be appropriate for patients who require skilled care services. However, assuming that a safe discharge can be ensured, the patient's needs and preferences should also be considered during discharge planning. Therefore, discharge to an assisted living facility without prior discussion with the patient and their family is inappropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Physicians should involve patients in decision-making processes (e.g., discharge planning) and respect their individual preferences. This patient with a history of stroke, hemiparesis, and mild cognitive impairment requires skilled medical services (e.g., physical therapy, skilled nursing care) and is unlikely to be able to travel to outpatient therapy. Therefore, a plan that only consists of regular outpatient visits is not feasible.

E) CORRECT:

The physician is responsible for assessing whether to involve a multidisciplinary team of discharge planners (usually social workers and/or nurses). Discharge planners can be especially helpful for patients who are at high risk for adverse events after discharge and require ongoing skilled care. Discharge planning should be initiated as early as possible and includes a psychosocial assessment, discharge counseling, medication reconciliation, planning of follow-up visits, and coordination of services. The patient, their family, and future caregivers should be involved to establish a plan that meets the patient's medical needs and personal preferences. Effective discharge planning can increase patient satisfaction, reduce the duration of hospitalization, and decrease readmission rates.

Home health care should be considered for patients who live at home and require complex ongoing care but are unable to travel. This form of rehabilitation reduces costs while avoiding the risks associated with prolonged hospitalization (e.g., nosocomial infections).
questions.hint: Discharge planning is the process of developing an individualized plan to ensure the safe transition of a patient from the hospital to another care setting (e.g., home health care, skilled nursing facility).

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is evaluated at the emergency department for nausea and abdominal pain. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows a distended appendix. She is diagnosed with acute appendicitis and scheduled for a laparoscopic appendectomy the next day. She is given nothing by mouth, and administration of intravenous fluids is begun. On the night before the surgery, she experiences severe abdominal pain and asks for pain medication. The physician on call prescribes intravenous acetaminophen. A nurse connects the medication to the patient's infusion set, opens one side clamp, and leaves the room. One hour later, the patient is still in severe pain and calls the physician again. The physician discovers an additional closed side clamp that he had not noticed in his past five years at the hospital. He opens the clamp, and the infusion starts to run. When the physician discusses the incident with his colleagues, someone says, We have two types of infusion sets in the hospital. This one is new. The underlying cause of the delay in this patient's treatment is best described by which of the following terms?

choices.text: Physician impairment
Latent error
Deprescribing
Workaround
Compassion fatigue

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Physician impairment is the inability to provide adequate medical care because of a psychiatric disorder, substance use disorder, or a condition that limits motor, cognitive, or perceptual skills. There is no evidence that either the physician or the nurse were impaired in this scenario. The underlying cause of the delay in this patient's treatment is best described by another term.

B) CORRECT:

A latent error (blunt end error) is an error in the design of a system (e.g., equipment, management) that predisposes individuals to make errors. Latent errors often go unnoticed; in combination with active errors, they can cause adverse events. In this scenario, the lack of equipment standardization was a latent error, and the nurse's failure to open both side clamps was an active error that resulted in delayed treatment. Other examples of latent errors include the storage of medications with similar packaging alongside each other and ineffective organizational structure. Reporting systems (e.g., an incident reporting system) can help to identify latent errors, reduce the likelihood of adverse events, and improve the overall quality of patient care. The majority of adverse events are caused by latent errors rather than by individual incompetence.

See "Overview of medical error types" table.

C) INCORRECT:

Deprescribing is the process of systematically identifying and discontinuing inappropriate medications. In this scenario, the physician prescribed acetaminophen, an appropriate medication, which was not properly administered to the patient.

D) INCORRECT:

A workaround is a temporary and/or quick solution typically implemented by frontline personnel to bypass systemic obstacles that prevent efficient work. Because workarounds do not address underlying structural problems, they can negatively affect patient safety in the long term. For example, a potential workaround in this scenario would be to remove all of the side clamps from the infusion sets so that they are already open. The underlying cause of the delay in this patient's treatment is best described by another term.

E) INCORRECT:

Compassion fatigue refers to the mental and physical exhaustion experienced by healthcare personnel because of long-term patient care. This condition can result in emotional withdrawal, irritability, lack of empathy, and negative coping behaviors (e.g., alcohol or drug use) and may cause medical workers to commit errors and neglect patient care. Neither the physician nor the nurse in this scenario has features of compassion fatigue. The underlying cause of the delay in this patient's treatment is best described by another term.
questions.hint: Standardization of infusion sets could have prevented the delay in treatment.

questions.text: The head of a private surgical daycare clinic is evaluating the results of a recent cost-benefit analysis. The results indicate that it may be more economical to purchase multidose vials instead of individual prefilled syringes for injectable drugs. To reduce costs, the clinic pharmacy decides to transition from buying injectable operating room drugs in prefilled single-dose syringes to bulk packages of multidose vials that have to be prepared for single-use injection. An anesthesiologist raises the concern that multidose vials increase the risk of perioperative medication errors. If the clinic continues to purchase multidose vials, which of the following actions is most likely to maximize patient safety?

choices.text: Drawing up and labeling of drugs in the on-site pharmacy before surgery
Drawing up of drugs by the circulating nurse during surgery based on instructions by the anesthetist
Drawing up of drugs by the anesthesiologist during surgery
Drawing up of drugs by a scrub nurse before surgery based on the patient's diagnosis
Drawing up and labeling of drugs by the surgeon before surgery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Drugs that are commonly required during surgery should be prepared beforehand and should always be readily available. Involving the on-site pharmacist is a key step to prevent drug dispensing errors. If multiple patients receive doses from the same vial (as seen in multidose vials), drug dispensing for the operating room should take place in a clean area reserved for medication preparation (e.g., a satellite pharmacy) and in an aseptic manner (e.g., using sterile syringes, disinfecting the septum before piercing the vial). Preparing drug trays with prefilled syringes in conjunction with clear labeling (e.g., with the drug's generic name and drug concentration) using standardized printed labels maximizes patient safety by reducing the risk of product mix-ups and dispensing errors. The label may also include the date, time, pharmacist's name, and the patient's name and date of birth.

B) INCORRECT:

Circulating nurses have a number of responsibilities during surgery, such as providing additional equipment when needed, and are often responsible for more than one surgical team. Therefore, there would be an increased risk of attentional capture and skill-based errors if the circulating nurse prepared the drugs; a different person should be designated for drug dispensing. In addition, drugs that are commonly required during surgery should be prepared prior to surgery and always readily available.

C) INCORRECT:

Anesthesiologists have a high cognitive workload and carry out multiple important tasks during surgery (e.g., administering and managing anesthesia, monitoring and controlling patients' vital functions and level of consciousness). Therefore, there would be an increased risk of attentional capture and skill-based errors if the anesthesiologist was responsible for drawing up drugs during surgery. Moreover, the anesthesiologist works in the immediate patient area, and dispensing drugs in this area is not recommended, as it increases the risk of contamination.

D) INCORRECT:

Scrub nurses have a number of responsibilities prior to surgery, such as reviewing patients' records, adjusting surgical instruments, adhering to the universal protocol, and scrubbing up. The scrub nurse is not responsible for drawing up and labeling drugs. Additionally, in environments such as the operating room or the emergency department, the patient's diagnosis is often not the most crucial factor in determining what medications need to be prepared, as standardized protocols for specific situations are often used.

E) INCORRECT:

Before surgery, the surgeon is responsible for preparing the operation (e.g., reviewing the patient's records, confirming their diagnosis and thus the indication for the planned procedure). Additionally, the surgeon needs to scrub up and, as the leader of the surgical team, is also responsible for briefing the team and adherence to the universal protocol. The operating surgeon is not responsible for drawing up and labeling drugs.
questions.hint: The use of multidose vials instead of prefilled single-dose syringes increases the risk of medication dispensing errors and contamination.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is evaluated after developing acute kidney injury while receiving cisplatin chemotherapy following resection of a T3N0M0 stage IIB non-small-cell lung cancer.
Laboratory results are notable for a blood urea nitrogen level of 54 mg/dL (reference range, 1020) and a serum creatinine level of 4.6 mg/dL (0.81.3). At his previous evaluation 4 weeks ago, his blood urea nitrogen level was 14 mg/dL, and his serum creatinine level was 0.8 mg/dL.
Initial review of the patients records reveals that he did not receive the necessary intravenous volume expansion with the cisplatin chemotherapy. The treating health care provider wrote the order for 1000 mL of intravenous saline to be given during the several hours prior to cisplatin administration, but for some reason that fluid bolus was not administered.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for the treating health care provider?

choices.text: Ask the hospital attorney to meet with and apologize to the patient
Explain that nephrotoxicity is a known side effect of cisplatin
Postpone discussion of the error with the patient until a full investigation of the circumstances leading to the error has been completed
Get advice from the hospitals ethics consult service
Explain the error now, and apologize to the patient

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the hospital attorney or risk-management team will usually become involved in cases like this, it is the treating health care providers responsibility to acknowledge and discuss the error with the patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Lying or attributing the cause of the error to another etiology is unethical; it is the treating providers responsibility to disclose the error and apologize for it.

C) INCORRECT:

Although health care providers might be reluctant to disclose errors because they are embarrassed or fear litigation, telling the truth shortly after the error is discovered is ethically obligatory and is the accepted standard of care. Acknowledging a medical error and apologizing for it is only the first step in managing the error; health care systems also need to identify the root cause and address knowledge and system gaps to ensure that the error is not repeated. However, initial discussion with the patient and acknowledgement of the error should not be delayed while the investigation is ongoing.

D) INCORRECT:

An ethics consultation might be helpful later on if an ethical dilemma arises, but it is unnecessary at this stage.

E) CORRECT:

Although health care providers might be reluctant to disclose errors because they are embarrassed or fear litigation, telling the truth shortly after the error is discovered is ethically obligatory and is the accepted standard of care. Acknowledging a medical error and apologizing for it is only the first step in managing the error; health care systems also need to identify the root cause and address knowledge and system gaps to ensure that the error is not repeated. However, initial discussion with the patient and acknowledgement of the error should not be delayed while the investigation is ongoing.

The National Quality Forum recommends that when disclosing a medical error, the health care provider should provide relevant information surrounding the events, express regret for the unanticipated outcome, and give a formal apology.

Key learning point: The proper way to communicate an iatrogenic medical error that causes harm to a patient is to provide an early, open, honest account of the error and apologize formally to the patient.

questions.text:
While awaiting upper endoscopy, a 31-year-old woman with hematemesis and acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding receives a transfusion containing one unit of packed red cells. Approximately 15 minutes into the transfusion, the patient develops chills, fever, chest pain, and hypotension.
One of the nurses realizes that the administered blood product had been intended for a trauma patient with a similar last name.
The transfusion is stopped, urgent therapy is given, and the blood bank is notified.
What error-prevention strategy should be emphasized in debriefing the medical team after this critical incident?

choices.text: Ask the patient to identify his or her blood group before administering a transfusion
Routinely confirm with the patient that he or she was expecting a transfusion before administering it
Encourage providers to speak up if they spot an error
Check at least two patient identifiers before administering a transfusion
Designate one health care provider to oversee the entire transfusion process from order to administration

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Few patients know their blood group and recall it accurately, so self-reported blood group is considered unreliable.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients are sometimes unaware of or have misunderstood the providers plans for a transfusion. Asking an awake, competent patient to state his or her name before the transfusion is generally recommended but on its own, it might not have prevented the error in this case.

C) INCORRECT:

Speaking up when observing an error is important, but on its own, it would not have prevented the error in this case.

D) CORRECT:

This patients symptoms of fever, chest pain, and hypotension support the diagnosis of an acute hemolytic reaction caused by the transfusion of ABO-incompatible blood. Most hemolytic reactions are caused by human error. Therefore, in high-stakes situations, such as transfusion of blood products, the standard of care is to verify the patient's identity using at least two identifiers (such as name, medical record number, and date of birth listed on wristband) before transfusing blood.

Key learning point: Potentially fatal complications from transfusion of a mismatched blood product can be avoided by verifying the patients identity using at least two identifiers (e.g., name, medical record number, date of birth listed on wristband).

E) INCORRECT:

Limiting the blood-transfusion process to a single provider, from the initial order to the moment of transfusion, may minimize mistakes associated with handoffs. However, even if one provider ordered and gave the transfusion, the patient's identity must be verified before transfusing blood to ensure that the correct blood is given to the correct patient.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of frontal and temporal headaches. She reports that the headaches occur several times per month and are preceded by bright flashing lights, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound. She does not describe any associated visual or speech changes, tearing, nasal congestion, fatigue, joint pain, scalp tenderness, or jaw pain with chewing. She is asymptomatic between headache episodes.
Her vital signs are within normal limits, and a neurologic examination is normal.
You recall an older patient who presented with nonspecific headaches several months ago and was ultimately diagnosed with temporal arteritis. You decide to order a complete blood count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate for the current patient.
Which one of the following cognitive biases is most likely affecting the decision to order these blood tests in this patient?

choices.text: Framing effects
Unconscious ignorance
Anchoring
Availability heuristic
Failure to account for the sensitivity and specificity of the tests ordered

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Framing effects, in which providers allow subtle cues and collateral information to unduly bias decision-making. A classic example is when clinicians or patients make different choices about testing or treatment depending on whether the associated risk information is presented in a positive light (survival) or a negative one (mortality).

B) INCORRECT:

Diagnostic errors can result from unconscious ignorance, in which providers are not aware of the knowledge they do not possess.

C) INCORRECT:

Anchoring heuristic, in which providers rely too heavily on the initial information they receive and decide on a diagnosis prematurely without fully considering all the available information. For example, a provider might formulate a diagnosis on the basis of initial clinical impressions and then fail to consider alternative diagnoses as additional information, such as laboratory or imaging results, becomes available.

D) CORRECT:

Understanding cognitive heuristics (mental shortcuts used in reasoning) and thinking about one's own cognitive processes (metacognition) may lead to increased awareness of biases and improved diagnostic accuracy.

In this particular case, the provider's error (ordering unnecessary blood tests) is most likely due to the availability heuristic, a mental shortcut in which an individual misjudges the likelihood of an event based on how quickly or easily they can retrieve information and examples. This provider recalled the recent case of temporal arteritis and then overestimated the current patient's probability of having the same diagnosis, even though the diagnosis of temporal arteritis is not plausible in a young patient whose presentation is classic for migraine headache.

Diagnostic errors are best avoided through education and awareness of the cognitive processes involved in reaching decisions.

Key learning point: The type of cognitive bias that occurs when the evaluation of a current patient is affected by recall of recent cases is called the availability heuristic.

E) INCORRECT:

Blind obedience, in which providers fail to think about a diagnosis critically in the face of human authority or technology. For example, a provider might rely too heavily on a particular diagnostic test and fail to account for the testing characteristics (such as sensitivity and specificity) that affect its predictive value.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman with a history of severe ischemic cardiomyopathy and chronic renal insufficiency is being discharged after hospitalization for an exacerbation of heart failure. Her presenting symptoms of orthopnea and peripheral edema have responded well to several days of diuresis. A previous echocardiogram, performed when the patient was euvolemic, showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%.
The patient's medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, carvedilol, spironolactone, and furosemide. She also requires hearing aids for a hearing impairment.
The patient is intermittently adherent to her medications and frequently eats prepared foods that are high in sodium. She lives with her daughter and has adequate financial support. The daughter has agreed to obtain a pill box from the pharmacy and to monitor her mother's medication and dietary adherence.
Which one of the following intervention strategies would most effectively reduce this patients risk of readmission?

choices.text: Assign a staff member to follow up on laboratory results that return after discharge and call the patient at home to ask about postdischarge needs
Link the patient's inpatient and outpatient medications electronically and alert her primary care provider when she is discharged
Provide the patient with intensive dietary education and a written emergency plan at discharge and then contact her at home after discharge
Arrange the patient's follow-up appointments before discharge and send an electronic discharge summary directly to her primary care provider

Review the discharge summary with the patient and send it directly to her primary care provider, assign a nurse to provide medication reconciliation and teaching at discharge, and arrange follow-up appointments before discharge

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Following up on laboratory results is prudent and appropriate, but it has not been formally proven to reduce readmissions. Calling the patient at home about post-discharge needs is a component of some effective programs, but there is little evidence of its efficacy.

B) INCORRECT:

Medication reconciliation is a key part of the discharge process. Linking inpatient and outpatient medications electronically is not necessarily the same as medication reconciliation. Alerting the patients primary care provider about discharge is not as effective as actually ensuring that the patient has appropriate follow-up appointments in place. Even if follow-up appointments are put into place, assigning a nurse to provide medication reconciliation and teaching at discharge is essential as part of an optimal discharge process.

C) INCORRECT:

Education at discharge needs to focus on more than just diet and an emergency plan.

D) INCORRECT:

In a patient with heart failure, the most important elements to prevent readmission are having a nurse perform detailed medication teaching before discharge, arranging follow-up appointments before discharge, and sending the discharge summary to the patient's primary care provider within 48 hours of discharge. Interventions that combine components of the discharge process are associated with a lower risk of hospital readmission than those that focus on single components.

E) CORRECT:

Readmissions can be reduced effectively by focusing on several areas of the discharge process. The interventions that can help reduce readmission rates are as follows:

Creating partnerships between hospitals and community providers, local group medical practices, and other local hospitals
Assigning nurses the responsibility of performing medication reconciliation at discharge
Coordinating the patient's discharge with outside physicians, including arranging follow-up appointments before discharge and sending an electronic discharge summary to the patients primary care provider
Assigning a staff member to follow up on laboratory results that are still pending at discharge

Patients with advanced heart failure have among the highest rates of hospital readmission. In a patient with heart failure, the most important elements to prevent readmission are having a nurse perform detailed medication teaching before discharge, arranging follow-up appointments before discharge, and sending the discharge summary to the patient's primary care provider within 48 hours of discharge. Interventions that combine components of the discharge process are associated with a lower risk of hospital readmission than those that focus on single components.

Researchers have recently introduced the concept of post-hospitalization syndrome, a period of vulnerability in which discharged patients are at risk for readmissions that are unrelated to the initial diagnosis. This risk results from the physiologic stressors commonly encountered during hospitalization, such as sleep deprivation, poor nutrition, poor pain control, and deconditioning. Strategies to mitigate post-hospitalization syndrome require efforts to target these risk factors during hospitalization and to have appropriate outpatient support and follow-up.

Key learning point: The most effective intervention strategies to prevent hospital readmission in a patient who has advanced heart failure include assigning nurses to provide medication reconciliation and teaching at discharge, partnering with primary care providers, and scheduling follow-up appointments before discharge.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents with fatigue, and a complete blood count is performed. The results show pancytopenia with decreased cell counts in all three cell lines  but the findings are never followed up on. Six months later, the patient presents again with progressive fatigue, and follow-up evaluation reveals findings that are most consistent with a diagnosis of hairy-cell leukemia.
A root cause analysis is performed to explore the lack of follow-up on the initial laboratory results. A step-by-step review of the process that led to the problem is performed, and the proximate causes and contributing factors have been determined and analyzed.
What is the most appropriate next step in the root cause analysis?

choices.text: Assess the attitudes of the health care team toward error prevention
Evaluate the current information technology for laboratory management
Create an action plan to assign responsibilities to prevent similar errors in the future
Conduct an evaluation of staff workload
Create a flowchart to illustrate the sequence of key events in this case

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Assessing the attitudes of the health care team toward error prevention would be performed as a part of participant interviews (the first step of root cause analysis) and analyzing the proximate causes and contributing factors (the third step of root cause analysis). These steps have been completed, and the final step of a root cause analysis should be performed.

B) INCORRECT:

Evaluation of information technology management would be performed as a part of the third step of root cause analysis, in which proximate causes and contributing factors are analyzed. This step has been completed, and the final step of a root cause analysis should be performed.

C) CORRECT:

Once a proximate cause and the human factors have been identified for a systems problem, the next step in a root cause analysis is to develop an action plan for system-wide change.

Root cause analysis (RCA) is a structured error analysis tool used for evaluating serious adverse events. The goal of the tool is to identify key areas for system redesign to prevent future adverse events.

The first step in an RCA is to conduct participant interviews and a chart review to create a detailed, step-by-step review of the process that led to the event. The second step involves identification of proximate causes or errors that were involved in the event or, in this case, the providers failure to follow up on study results.

The third step is a structured analysis of factors that contributed to the adverse event. This step is a more global approach to human-factors analysis that looks at communication structures, human resource and leadership structures, environmental issues, and information management issues. In this case, this step is exemplified by evaluation of staff training and workload and evaluation of information technology management.

The final and most important step in an RCA is the creation of an action plan for how to modify the existing process to prevent future adverse events and medical errors. In this case, the action plan would involve having the provider and nurse on call for the day be responsible for reviewing all of the new laboratory and study results obtained that day, following up appropriately on those results, and disseminating the information to all involved parties.

Key learning point: The final step in a root cause analysis is to develop an action plan for system-wide change.

D) INCORRECT:

Evaluation of staff training and workload would be performed as a part of the third step of root cause analysis, in which proximate causes and contributing factors are analyzed. This step has been completed, and the final step of a root cause analysis should be performed.

E) INCORRECT:
