Process mapping (e.g., by creating a flowchart to illustrate the sequence of key events) is performed in the first and second steps of a root cause analysis as a part of determining proximate causes and contributing factors. These steps and the subsequent step of analyzing proximate causes and contributing factors have been completed.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain and swelling in his left leg that began after he fell doing yard work 2 days ago. When ordering the radiograph, you inadvertently choose the option for a radiograph of his right leg, and a radiograph of the right leg is obtained.
In addition to explaining the next steps in care to the patient, what is the most appropriate action to take regarding the error?

choices.text: Explain to the patient that you inadvertently ordered a radiograph of the wrong leg and apologize
Explain to the patient that the wrong order was transmitted to the radiology department
Contact risk-management staff before discussing the error with the patient
Order a new imaging study without disclosing the error to the patient
Ask a nurse to explain to the patient that additional imaging will be needed

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Patients expect and deserve to be treated in a timely, thoughtful, and respectful manner and this expectation includes disclosure of medical errors if and when they occur. In the United States, the National Quality Forum recommends that clinicians disclose medical errors to patients in a timely manner and include the following components in the disclosure:

An explanation of the error and the events that led to it
An apology for the error
A discussion about how to minimize the effects of the error
A discussion about steps being taken to prevent similar errors in the future

Apologies should be specific and direct (such as I'm sorry that I ordered the wrong radiograph) rather than indirect or evasive (such as I'm sorry this happened to you or Im sorry youre so upset about this). Explanations that describe that "the wrong order was transmitted or that an error occurred are inadequate.

Attempting to resolve a medical error (in this case, by obtaining the correct image) without disclosing the error to the patient is not appropriate. It is essential to partner with the patient and other members of the medical team to ensure optimal continued care.

Key learning point: The three key steps in resolving a medical error are disclosure, apology, and discussion of next steps.

B) INCORRECT:

Apologies should be specific and direct (such as I'm sorry that I ordered the wrong radiograph) rather than indirect or evasive (such as I'm sorry this happened to you or Im sorry youre so upset about this). Explanations that describe that "the wrong order was transmitted or that an error occurred are inadequate.

C) INCORRECT:

The involvement of risk-management staff after a medical error depends on individual institutional guidelines, the severity of the event, and individual provider preference. In this particular case, involving risk-management staff after the explanation and apology would be an option but not an absolute necessity.

D) INCORRECT:

Attempting to resolve a medical error (in this case, by obtaining the correct image) without disclosing the error to the patient is not appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Attempting to resolve a medical error (in this case, by obtaining the correct image) without disclosing the error to the patient is not appropriate.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man reports frequent episodes of lightheadedness for the past 10 days. He states that he is tired but not dizzy at the moment and that his lightheadedness occurs most often when he makes the transition from lying down to standing. He has a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and coronary artery disease. His medications at his last visit 6 months ago were hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, atorvastatin, and insulin. His blood pressure at his last office visit was 127/85 mm Hg.
He was discharged 2 weeks ago from another facility, where he was hospitalized for pneumonia. He is now afebrile, and his cough has improved.
Which one of the following evaluations is most likely to reveal the cause of this patients symptoms?

choices.text: Perform medication reconciliation to specifically review discharge medications
Schedule an echocardiogram
Compare the electrocardiogram from this evaluation with the one from the other hospital
Obtain the results of the microbiologic culture from the other hospital
Review the results of peak flow testing from the other hospital

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medication reconciliation involves verifying a patients medication lists at a transition point in care, such as at a follow-up visit after hospital discharge. The purpose of this process is to correctly identify which medications are new, which have been stopped, and which have been changed. Correct reconciliation of medications is essential for avoiding the introduction of unintended changes to medication regimens and may help to prevent hospital readmissions.

In this case, the patients lightheadedness began shortly after hospital discharge, seems orthostatic, and is very likely attributable to antihypertensive medications. Admission to the hospital often results in inadvertent changes to medication regimens, including errors of omission as well as duplication. Only a thorough medication reconciliation can uncover such discrepancies. Systematic reviews have shown that medication reconciliation is associated with reductions in risk for actual and potential adverse drug events.

Key learning point: When a patient who was recently discharged from the hospital on a prescribed medication regimen presents with new or worsening symptoms, the patients medication regimens should be reconciled.

B) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram is unnecessary in the absence of auscultatory or other physical examination findings that suggest a structural or functional abnormality of the heart.

C) INCORRECT:

Obtaining test results from a previous hospitalization, such as microbiology, peak flow, and electrocardiogram findings, can be useful. However, this step should be taken after addressing the patients symptoms, and it would not identify the cause of the postural blood pressure changes in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Obtaining test results from a previous hospitalization, such as microbiology, peak flow, and electrocardiogram findings, can be useful. However, this step should be taken after addressing the patients symptoms, and it would not identify the cause of the postural blood pressure changes in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Obtaining test results from a previous hospitalization, such as microbiology, peak flow, and electrocardiogram findings, can be useful. However, this step should be taken after addressing the patients symptoms, and it would not identify the cause of the postural blood pressure changes in this case.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for difficulty breathing, increasing dyspnea on exertion, production of sputum, and wheezing. She has a 40-pack-year history of cigarette smoking and continues to actively smoke. Following evaluation, she is referred for bronchoscopy. Immediately after the procedure is complete, the bronchoscopist is called to the emergency department and quickly leaves the bronchoscopy unit.
The patient returns to her room, reports mild dyspnea, and is treated with nebulized albuterol. Two hours after the bronchoscopy, she develops respiratory distress and quickly becomes hypotensive and unresponsive. She improves only after needle decompression to treat what is eventually recognized as a pneumothorax.
After further review of the patients records, it is discovered that an unplanned transbronchial biopsy was performed.
Which one of the following strategies could have helped this patient's doctors to recognize the cause of her decompensation more quickly?

choices.text: Use of a structured template for the handover after bronchoscopy
Delivery of a lecture about post-bronchoscopy care
Implementation of routine post-bronchoscopy monitoring with continuous pulse oximetry
Use of a checklist to ensure measurement of vital signs on an hourly basis after bronchoscopy
Introduction of a process improvement measure to ensure routine post-bronchoscopy chest radiography

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Handoffs and transitions in care are becoming increasingly frequent in hospitals. Certain transitions in care, including those that occur after procedures, are particularly risky.

The most effective patient handovers occur in a structured format, using templates, tools, and checklists, so that all necessary information is communicated. Most handover tools include a patient summary, information on illness severity, action items, and contingency planning. A read-back by the receiver improves the quality of the handover. These approaches to interprofessional communication are associated with reduced rates of adverse events and are widely recommended.

In this particular case, a more complete handover with inclusion of the biopsy would have allowed the responding clinicians to recognize and address the cause of the patient's hypotension more quickly. There is a significantly higher risk of post-procedural pneumothorax when transbronchial biopsies are performed. Appropriate treatment for the pneumothorax (chest tube placement) could have been performed before the patient decompensated.

Key learning point: A successful handover practice between clinical teams is best achieved using structured templates, tools, and checklists.

B) INCORRECT:

Although a lecture about post-bronchoscopy care could have been helpful, it is unlikely to have been useful if the team was not aware that a transbronchial biopsy was performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Post-bronchoscopy monitoring with continuous pulse oximetry would not have allowed for early detection of the pneumothorax.

D) INCORRECT:

The care providers must be informed that a transbronchial biopsy was performed because this information improves their situational awareness and helps them recognize and respond to a pneumothorax faster than if they were only measuring vital signs at specific intervals. Checklists are useful for ensuring all necessary steps are taken during a transition of care process, but checklists are by themselves not a cure-all and may not be effective if standard safety practices are not already established.

E) INCORRECT:

Routine post-bronchoscopy chest radiography represents an inappropriate use of resources and is not routinely recommended. Obtaining a chest radiograph after every bronchoscopy is not indicated because the risk of pneumothorax is almost negligible in patients undergoing simple inspection or lavage. In many institutions, a chest radiograph is obtained after transbronchial biopsies, but even this practice has been brought into question after a single-center study showed no harm in ordering films only based on symptoms (rather than routinely after biopsies). A policy requiring chest radiographs after every procedure would be wasteful, given that many unnecessary studies would be obtained.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old boy is hospitalized with pneumonia in the right middle lobe. One month ago, at an urgent care center not affiliated with this hospital, he was given a course of amoxicillin-clavulanate for acute otitis media and developed urticaria and respiratory distress that required administration of intramuscular epinephrine.
Now, prior to inpatient rounds, you attempt to expedite treatment of the patients pneumonia and order intravenous ampicillin. You receive an alert but automatically override it, assuming it is a false alarm. The patients nurse notices the ordering error, contacts you, and does not administer the ampicillin.
Which one of the following plans would best prevent a similar event in the future?

choices.text: Require pharmacist participation during rounds
Develop an educational program about antibiotic allergy for the professional staff
Implement bar-code technology to correctly link a patient with his or her ordered medication
Use allergy alert bracelets for all patients with a history of allergic reaction
Implement a tiered system for allergy alerts in the electronic medical record system

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although pharmacist participation during rounds can help educate prescribers and reduce adverse events from medication interactions, it would not have prevented this error, because this error occurred before formal rounds.

B) INCORRECT:

Education of health care providers by itself is generally a weak intervention to reduce errors. Moreover, many errors occur in the setting of distractions or lapses in memory rather than lack of knowledge.

C) INCORRECT:

Bar-code technology may reduce errors in drug transcription and administration, but it would not have prevented a prescribing error such as this one. Bar-coding does represent a final line of defense, because an allergy in the medical record could generate an alert to the nurse. But, here, too, there is the risk of alert fatigue, so the bar-coding approach offers no advantage over an alert system to prevent errors like the one that occurred in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Allergy alert bracelets identify patients with allergies and are effective at preventing ordering and administration errors caused by lack of awareness of an allergy. However, the error in this case did not involve lack of awareness of the allergy.

E) CORRECT:

Ampicillin is an absolute contraindication for this patient, given his history of anaphylaxis to a medication containing amoxicillin. Fortunately, the nurse noticed the prescribing error and was able to prevent a potentially serious adverse effect, which makes this a near-miss event.

Although there are many approaches to reducing adverse events caused by medication allergies, the development of computerized order-entry systems with decision support, including allergy alerts, has been shown to be particularly effective in reducing prescribing errors. However, not all alerts have equal clinical significance, and the frequency of alerts can lead to clinician fatigue. One practical strategy is to use a tiered approach to applying alerts instead of using them for all possible oversights or errors in ordering. With this approach, a small subset of very dangerous clinical situations would generate alerts that either demand a response from the ordering clinician or, in a few select cases, even force a change to the intended order, with a reduction in the risk of clinician override.

Key learning point: A situation with the potential to cause serious harm that does not result in injury to the patient is known as a near-miss event.

questions.text: The type and screen vial for a 14-year-old girl with severe anemia is mislabeled, and she develops a transfusion reaction after she receives the mismatched packed red cells. What is the most appropriate goal of a root-cause analysis that is set up to address this event?

choices.text: To develop a new process for screening blood products for pathogens to optimize safety of the blood supply
To minimize any potential litigation that may arise from the incident
To ensure that education is provided to the most appropriate members of the health care team
To investigate cognitive and structural factors that contributed to the event so that they can be communicated to the patients family
To identify human and systems-based factors that contributed to the event and to develop actions that will prevent future adverse outcomes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because this event was not related to an infected blood product, the root-cause analysis is unlikely to lead to a change in screening blood products for pathogens.

B) INCORRECT:

Strong communication may reduce the likelihood of legal action, but minimizing any potential litigation is not the purpose of a root-cause analysis.

C) INCORRECT:

Education is an important component after a sentinel event, but identifying the correct focus for additional education is not the purpose of a root-cause analysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Honest and open communication with families is essential. Although it is important to discuss actions that will be taken to prevent future events, it may not be appropriate to reveal all the details of the root-cause analysis, such as cognitive and structural factors that contributed to the event, with the patient's family.

E) CORRECT:

A sentinel event is an unexpected occurrence involving death, serious injury, or the risk of death of serious injury. A sentinel event should precipitate an immediate investigation and response. A root-cause analysis, which includes a detailed chronology of the specific events leading up to the event and identification of factors contributing to the event, should be conducted as soon as possible.

The goal of the root-cause analysis is to identify and implement systems-wide strategies to prevent similar adverse outcomes in the future. When a serious error occurs in health care, we often assume that we know the cause (e.g., the nurse should have checked the vial [or the label]), when in fact multiple aspects of the work environment (such as the distractions frequently encountered in clinical settings), the design of equipment (in this case, vials and labels), the reliance on human vigilance as the main safety system, and a number of other possible factors may have played a role. A formal root-cause analysis ensures that relevant categories of cause are considered including equipment design and maintenance, communication, teamwork, existing procedures and policies, and human factors, such as fatigue and scheduling.

Key learning point: The purpose of a root-cause analysis following a sentinel event is to identify human and systems-based factors that contributed to the event and to develop actions that will reduce future adverse outcomes.

questions.text: An 11-month-old boy receives an excessively high dose of morphine because the dose was calculated based on his body weight in pounds (rather than kilograms). He develops respiratory depression requiring bag-mask ventilation but recovers after he is treated with naloxone. Beyond apologizing, which one of the following approaches should be used in disclosing this error to the patients family?

choices.text: Explain that an error occurred but that the hospital will not conduct a formal investigation because the patient recovered quickly
Express regret about the event, and explain that respiratory depression is a known adverse effect of morphine
Explain how the patient received an incorrect dose of morphine, and discuss what will be done to prevent similar errors in the future
Explain that an error has occurred, but do not provide specific details or accept responsibility, given the potential for litigation
Explain that the nurse is responsible because she incorrectly entered the patients weight into the electronic medical record and that she will be appropriately disciplined

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Even if the patient did not suffer long-term sequelae from the medical error, an error that harmed a patient should be subjected to a root-cause analysis.

B) INCORRECT:

Concealing that this patient received an incorrect dose of morphine would be unethical, even if respiratory depression is a known adverse effect of opioids.

C) CORRECT:

Health care providers have an ethical, professional, and often legal obligation to disclose serious medical errors to patients and their families. However, factors such as embarrassment, remorse, and fear of possible litigation can make the process challenging.

Disclosure of a medical error should include meeting with the patients family to honestly describe what happened and to show sympathy. The provider should offer an apology without placing blame, listen to the familys concerns, and explain how similar errors can be prevented in the future. Disclosing all the details of the error is not necessary, but the provider should be honest with the family. Open communication may actually reduce the likelihood of legal action. However, the purpose of the disclosure is not to place blame on particular individuals.

Even if the patient did not suffer long-term sequelae from the medical error, an error that harmed a patient should be subjected to a root-cause analysis.

Key learning point: After a medical error that resulted in harm to a patient, the best approach is one that emphasizes honesty and empathy without placing blame.

D) INCORRECT:

Disclosing all the details of the error is not necessary, but the provider should be honest with the family. Open communication may actually reduce the likelihood of legal action.

E) INCORRECT:

The provider should offer an apology without placing blame, listen to the familys concerns, and explain how similar errors can be prevented in the future. The purpose of the disclosure is not to place blame on particular individuals.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl is admitted from the emergency department for treatment of community-acquired bacterial pneumonia. After receiving her first dose of intravenous ampicillin, she develops lip and facial swelling with diffuse hives. She has a documented amoxicillin allergy.
After appropriate management of the anaphylaxis, which one of the following explanations is the most appropriate one to give to this patient and her family?

choices.text: Explain that you are not sure what happened but that you suspect an allergic reaction to the antibiotic
Disclose the medical error, and apologize to the patient and her family on behalf of the entire medical team
Disclose the medical error, and encourage the family to discuss the incident with the hospitals quality improvement officer
Disclose the medical error, and apologize to the patient and her family on behalf of the emergency department team
Explain that allergic reactions are common and promise to investigate what happened

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Stating you are not sure what happened when the patient has a known medication allergy would be inappropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Research shows that when a medical error occurs, patients and their families want to be made aware of it promptly. They wish to understand how the error occurred and the implications for the patients care, regardless of whether direct harm ensued. They also want to receive a genuine apology that accepts responsibility and to know that the responsible health care professional and the system will learn from the error and prevent its recurrence.

Fear of litigation and an increase in malpractice claims have served as barriers to full disclosure of medical errors in the United States, but many health systems have seen malpractice claims stay the same or decrease in number after instituting open-disclosure policies. Despite the legal concerns, full disclosure of a medical error upholds the health care providers ethical duty to tell the truth to his or her patients and enhances patients ability to make informed decisions about their medical care. Overall, organizational, regulatory, and legal policies support the prompt, full disclosure of medical errors to patients.

Key learning point: The most appropriate way to explain a medical error to a 12-year-old patient and his or her family is to promptly disclose the error and apologize to the patient and family on behalf of the entire medical team.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the hospital quality improvement officer should be involved, an apology on behalf of the entire medical team should come first.

D) INCORRECT:

Apologizing on behalf of only the emergency department team (and not including the floor team) inappropriately narrows the blame. That approach is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Simply noting that allergic reactions are common when the patient has a known medication allergy would be inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl with a history of obesity, anxiety, and suspected pseudotumor cerebri is scheduled for a lumbar puncture (LP) under conscious sedation. Sedation is achieved after the patient receives three doses of midazolam and fentanyl.
The LP procedure is prolonged, the previous sedation provider is replaced, and the new provider orders another dose of midazolam. After this fourth dose of midazolam, the patient experiences respiratory depression and requires flumazenil rescue. The procedure is aborted.
Which one of the following interventions is most likely to prevent errors similar to the one in this case?

choices.text: A structured patient-care handoff
A requirement for labeling for all medications that have been removed from their original packaging
Use of a bedside clinical pharmacist to administer intravenous sedation
A timeout before medication administration
A review of all of the patients allergies before medication administration

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medical errors often occur in high-risk situations, including those involving provider stress, fatigue, distraction, or burnout. This patients medical error occurred in the setting of transfer of care. Although an error such as this could be caused by training or other factors specific to the provider, most medical errors result from systems issues. The root-cause analysis of this event should include a close review of systems-related processes.

A standardized or structured handoff procedure such as situation, background, assessment, recommendations (SBAR) would ideally have included information about the patients previous doses of midazolam. A structured approach to the handoff would increase the likelihood that the new provider would be able to avoid a medication error. SBAR and similar techniques have been shown to improve patient safety in settings similar to the one in this case.

Key learning point: In a transfer of patient care from one provider to another, the recommended technique to optimize communication is a structured patient-care handoff.

B) INCORRECT:

Medication labeling is essential to preventing medication errors, such as overdose or incorrect administration. In this case, the midazolam was given as ordered, so the labeling was presumably accurate.

C) INCORRECT:

Use of a bedside clinical pharmacist has been shown to reduce the frequency of medication errors in intensive care units and oncology settings. However, their value has not been demonstrated in patient handoffs.

D) INCORRECT:

Timeouts are an accepted intervention to reduce medical errors, especially before procedures or surgeries. They provide a mandatory pause to confirm the patients name, identifying information, and procedure with all medical staff. Although a timeout should have happened before this patient's procedure, it most likely would not have prevented the medication overdose.

E) INCORRECT:

A patients allergies should be reviewed on admission, before administration of any medication, and before any new procedure is started. However, this patient experienced a midazolam overdose, not an allergic reaction.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy receives a threefold overdose of intravenous immunoglobulin while being treated for Kawasaki disease as an inpatient. What is the most appropriate response for minimizing the incidence of such errors?

choices.text: Introduce comprehensive clinical risk management
Develop a plan for medication reconciliation
Conduct a root-cause analysis
Implement a checklist-completion plan
Introduce no-fault voluntary safety-event reporting

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A clinical risk management system is a non-protocol-based, proactive intervention for error reduction. Heath care teams using this approach continuously review claims reports, near-miss events, adverse events, medical records, and patient surveys to identify risks to patient safety. They then apply their knowledge of these risks to create new protocols aimed at minimizing risk in the future. The introduction of a clinical risk management system is one possible intervention that could be recommended after a protocol-based analysis of the medical error.

B) INCORRECT:

Medication reconciliation is the process of reviewing a patients medication regimen at times of transition (i.e., admission or discharge) to avoid unintended inconsistencies that may harm patients. A different step to determine the underlying cause(s) of the medical error should be performed first.

C) CORRECT:

Root-cause analysis (RCA), a structured method of analyzing medical errors, has the dual goals of identifying the systems issues that increased the likelihood of an error while avoiding assignment of blame to the individual(s) involved. RCAs are structured according to a protocol that involves data gathering about an adverse event, such as this overdose. In an RCA, the members of the team reconstruct the steps that led to the event, collect information from the affected patients medical record, interview staff involved in the event, and eliminate latent errors that seem to have made an adverse event more likely.

Key learning point: A structured method by which a multidisciplinary team gathers data about an adverse medical event, reconstructs the sequence of steps before the event, examines the event itself, and develops a plan to eliminate underlying systems flaws is called a root-cause analysis.

D) INCORRECT:

Clinical checklists use algorithms to designate which actions to perform in a given clinical setting, so that no critical step in patient care is overlooked. A checklist is one possible intervention that could be recommended but it would not be appropriate to implement an intervention after a medical error without any review or analysis.

E) INCORRECT:

Voluntary patient-safety event reporting systems enable front-line medical personnel to report threats to patient safety while protecting their privacy and ensuring timely follow-up. The introduction of a voluntary patient-safety event reporting system is one possible intervention that could be recommended but it would not be appropriate to implement an intervention after a medical error without determining the underlying cause(s) of the medical error.

questions.text:
A 16-month-old girl has persistent otitis media in the right ear despite having been prescribed amoxicillin 10 days ago. With the help of a Spanish interpreter, you discover that her Spanish-speaking mother has been inadvertently giving the child a half-teaspoon instead of a full teaspoon of amoxicillin at each dose.
Which one of the following strategies is most likely to result in correct dosing of this childs medication at home?

choices.text: Have the pharmacy dispense a plastic syringe with the medication
Provide written instructions
Instruct the mother to buy a correctly sized kitchen spoon and limit its use to medication administration
Request intentional oversupply of the medication to compensate for predictable losses through spit up or spillage
Teach and then ask the mother to demonstrate the proper method to measure the medication

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The use of a dosing instrument necessitates instruction and demonstration to be maximally effective. Simply having the pharmacy dispense a measuring syringe may not lead to correct dosing of medication if it is not connected with teaching and teach back strategies to assess understanding.

B) INCORRECT:

Not all caregivers are literate, even in their own language. Therefore, written instructions are unreliable.

C) INCORRECT:

Kitchen spoons should not be used to dispense medications because their size is not standardized.

D) INCORRECT:

Although infants often spit back some of their medication, providing an oversupply of medication does not prevent dosing errors.

E) CORRECT:

More than 40% of caregivers make errors in dosing liquid medications. Advanced counseling strategies, informed by knowledge about health literacy, improve how providers communicate medication instructions to parents. These strategies include provider demonstration, use of pictures or drawings, and "teach back" or "show back."

Showing a caregiver the appropriate way to administer a liquid medication and then asking the caregiver to "show back" what she or he just learned is an effective strategy for communicating proper dosing to caregivers. People tend to remember information more when they have had to physically demonstrate it than when they have simply seen or heard it.

Key learning point: For a child who has been repeatedly given an inappropriately low dose of a liquid medication by a caregiver at home, the caregiver should be required to show that he or she can administer the appropriate dose in the office using a dosing instrument.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy with moderate persistent asthma and seasonal allergies is hospitalized for treatment of an asthma exacerbation. After the patient receives albuterol, ipratropium, and a 2-mg/kg loading dose of oral prednisolone in the emergency department, the admitting clinician orders 10 mg/kg of oral prednisolone every 12 hours rather than the intended dose of 1 mg/kg.
Which one of the following interventions could have prevented this dosing error?

choices.text: A medication-error training program for clinicians in the hospital
A linkage between emergency department and inpatient records so that all administered medications could be viewed on one dashboard
A requirement for a person-to-person handoff for admitted patients
Removal of medications with a high rate of dosing errors from the hospitals formulary
Use of a computerized provider order entry system that employs dose-range checking

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A medication training program may reduce prescribing errors. However, it would not have directly affected the outcome in this scenario and is not a systematic error-prevention mechanism.

B) INCORRECT:

Connecting emergency department (ED) and inpatient medical records can facilitate information sharing, but the prescribing error in this case was unrelated to ED-inpatient miscommunication.

C) INCORRECT:

Person-to-person handoffs can augment interdepartmental communication but would not have altered the course of this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Medications with a high rate of dosing errors can be removed from a formulary, but this strategy cannot be realistically applied in most circumstances, given that the medicines have a role in patient care. Prednisolone is used widely, so removing it from the formulary is unrealistic.

E) CORRECT:

Prescribing errors occur about three times more often in pediatric patients than in adult patients. Dosing challenges specific to children include weight-based dosing and dosing with age restrictions.

Computerized provider order entry is associated with a diminished risk for prescribing errors, but not with signi詮cantly fewer adverse drug events or lower mortality rates. Studies show dosing miscalculations as one of the most common medication safety problems in children.

Key learning point: With the switch to electronic medical records systems, pediatric hospitals have reduced prescribing errors by also adding computerized order entry that includes dose-range checking.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy with sickle cell anemia becomes difficult to arouse while being treated for dactylitis. Opioid toxicity is recognized as the cause for his somnolence; he responds quickly to treatment with naloxone. Review of his medications reveals an inadvertent administration of a dose of morphine that was 10 times higher than the prescribed dose.
The hospital has a computerized order entry system for medication orders. It does not include a mandatory weight-based calculator but does include a pop-up screen with text about the importance of weight-based dosing and a link to a dose calculator application.
Which one of the following strategies is most likely to reduce the probability that a similar error will occur in the same hospital?

choices.text: Implement a system of pharmacy-based dose verification for administering all opioid medications
Educate clinicians on the importance of using a computerized decision-support system, especially for weight-based dosing of morphine in children
Conduct a broad examination of all possible aspects of the childs care that could have contributed to the error, and perform multiple modifications in the overall care process
Identify the nurse who delivered the medication to determine why the incorrect dose was given
Implement a system in which nurses double-check medications that have a high risk of toxicity or of being administered in error

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A review of 250 major dosing errors in pediatric practice showed that about one-third involved errors at the administration stage rather than the ordering stage. This finding highlights the importance of investigating the full range of possible causes of medication errors.

B) INCORRECT:

In this case, several issues may be related to the design of the specific decision-support screen; for example, the text on the screen may be too long and unhelpful, and simply having the dose calculator come up directly might be better. It may also be that the institution has a problem with frequent "false alarms" for decision-support screens reminders that pop up with information or suggestions that are not relevant to the case at hand. Frequent incorrect alerts contribute to alert fatigue and increase the likelihood that clinicians will ignore appropriate warnings.

C) CORRECT:

A human factors approach to patient safety first defines the relationships among the multiple inputs, activities, and outputs that compose care processes and then aims to redesign care systems to improve provider performance and reduce hazards (or risk factors). This broader focus distinguishes a human factors approach from related, narrower paradigms (e.g., error prevention, harm prevention, and enhancement of evidence-based practice).

In this scenario, the inputs and potential hazards that may have contributed to the outcome include the patient's age, the related weight-based dosing, the ordering clinicians experience with weight-based dosing and opioid prescribing, and the checks in place from the pharmacy and nursing to verify appropriate dosing.

Without characterizing the degree to which each of these checks is working as intended, the institution might inappropriately focus on just one causal factor and miss other important opportunities for improvement. In this case, several issues may be related to the design of the specific decision-support screen; for example, the text on the screen may be too long and unhelpful, and simply having the dose calculator come up directly might be better. It may also be that the institution has a problem with frequent "false alarms" for decision-support screens reminders that pop up with information or suggestions that are not relevant to the case at hand. Frequent incorrect alerts contribute to alert fatigue and increase the likelihood that clinicians will ignore appropriate warnings.

Key learning point: Detailing the integral relationships among the inputs, activities, and outputs of care processes and designing processes to enhance provider performance constitutes an approach to patient safety called the human factors framework.

D) INCORRECT:

Discussing the error with nursing staff, highlighting the importance of decision support for ordering clinicians, or focusing solely on nursing or pharmacy processes may help to prevent future errors. However, in isolation, each approach does not acknowledge the relationships among inputs and activities (e.g., the clinician's experience with weight-based prescribing) that may have contributed to the dosing error.

E) INCORRECT:

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl with a history of recurrent migraines has typical features of acute migraine when she is brought to the emergency department by her mother. A dose of intravenous clindamycin (intended for a different patient) is inadvertently ordered and administered during her care. The patient is not adversely affected by the infusion and responds well to her standard migraine management.
What is the most appropriate way to manage this incident?

choices.text: File a safety report, and disclose the error to the mother
File a safety report, and disclose the error to both the patient and the mother
Do not disclose the error or file a safety report
File a safety report, but do not disclose the error to the patient or the mother
Disclose the error to the mother, but do not file a safety report

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Physicians are morally obligated to inform patients about medical errors, regardless of whether an adverse event occurred as a result of the error. Nondisclosure of errors violates the fiduciary physician-patient relationship, infringes on patients' autonomy by denying them the right to be fully informed as they consent to further care, and violates the principle of justice by denying individuals the opportunity to seek compensation.

For pediatric patients, studies have shown that most parents want to know of errors made during their child's care, even when there was no potential for harm. Furthermore, most parents want their child to be informed of errors, too, particularly if the child is older than 11 years. This preference is consistent with a physicians duty to include minors in their medical care to the extent to which it is developmentally appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

Physicians are morally obligated to inform patients about medical errors, regardless of whether an adverse event occurred as a result of the error. Nondisclosure of errors violates the fiduciary physician-patient relationship, infringes on patients' autonomy by denying them the right to be fully informed as they consent to further care, and violates the principle of justice by denying individuals the opportunity to seek compensation.

For pediatric patients, studies have shown that most parents want to know of errors made during their child's care, even when there was no potential for harm. Furthermore, most parents want their child to be informed of errors, too, particularly if the child is older than 11 years. This preference is consistent with a physicians duty to include minors in their medical care to the extent to which it is developmentally appropriate.

Filing a safety report is important but is not a substitute for discussing the error directly with the family. In this scenario, the physician should file a safety report and disclose the error to both the patient and the mother.

Key learning point: When a medical error occurs during the care of an adolescent patient, it should be disclosed to both the parents and the patient.

questions.text:
An 11-year-old girl and her 4-year-old brother present for well-child visits. After discussing the risks and benefits of immunizations for each child, the parents agree to all vaccines. However, the nurse accidentally administers the human papillomavirus vaccine to the 4-year-old boy and the measles-mumps-rubella vaccine to the 11-year-old girl.
Which one of the following processes is most likely to lead to detection of this error?

choices.text: Education of all clinic staff about the importance of reporting possible errors and adverse events to the clinic safety officer
Clinician review of a sample of medical records, looking for possible errors and adverse events
An active surveillance system with a standard survey administered daily to all clinic staff and families, soliciting any possible errors and adverse events
Monthly queries of the Vaccine Adverse Events Reporting System by clinic staff
An anonymous voluntary incident reporting system for possible errors and adverse events, available to all clinic staff

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Educating all clinic staff about the importance of error detection can be useful to promote a culture of safety in which individuals are not blamed but the system is improved. However, without additional reporting systems, education is unlikely to improve error detection significantly.

B) INCORRECT:

Comprehensive medical record review, as a single modality, has the highest yield for detection of errors and adverse events. However, this approach is resource intensive, and a review of only a sample of records is very likely to miss the records that reveal errors. In addition, in this case, it is possible that the error was not documented at all in the medical record, depending on the workflow of the nurse who administered the vaccines.

C) CORRECT:

Improvement efforts directed at patient safety depend on accurate and comprehensive detection of possible medical errors and adverse events. However, the process of detecting errors is complex in health care systems with busy clinicians. The highest-yield surveillance methods use multiple approaches, including comprehensive clinical reviews of medical records, frequent surveys of clinic staff and families, and an incident reporting system.

In this case, where children received the wrong vaccines, the error is most likely to be detected by the nurse who administered the vaccines or by the family.

Key learning point: The yield of error detection in a clinical practice increases significantly with an active surveillance system.

D) INCORRECT:

The Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) allows clinicians, staff, patients, and families to report suspected adverse events in real time after vaccine administration. It is used to generate hypotheses about potential vaccine-safety concerns and to investigate possible adverse events, not to detect errors in vaccine administration. Furthermore, it would require the nurse or family to take the initiative to log onto VAERS to make the report.

E) INCORRECT:

Although clinicians often use a voluntary incident-reporting system to document errors, the yield of error detection increases significantly with an active surveillance system whereby, for example, clinic staff and families are asked at the end of each day (or the end of each visit, for families) about any potential errors or adverse events.

Educating all clinic staff about the importance of error detection can be useful to promote a culture of safety in which individuals are not blamed but the system is improved. However, without additional reporting systems, education is unlikely to improve error detection significantly.

questions.text: A 10-month-old girl is admitted to the hospital because of left lower lobe pneumonia. Six months ago, she received a course of amoxicillin-clavulanate for acute otitis media from her primary care provider and developed urticaria and respiratory distress that required administration of intramuscular epinephrine. Before inpatient rounds, a physician at the hospital decides to initiate empirical treatment with intravenous ampicillin. When entering the patient's order, the physician receives an alert but overrides it, assuming it is a false alarm having received several false alarms in the past. The patients nurse notices the ordering error, contacts the physician, and does not administer ampicillin. Which of the following is the most appropriate systems intervention to prevent the type of medication error that occurred in this scenario?

choices.text: Use allergy alert bracelets for patients with a history of allergic reaction
Implement bar-code technology to correctly link a patient with their ordered medication
Require pharmacist participation during rounds
Implement a tiered system for allergy alerts in the electronic medical record system
Develop an educational program about antibiotic allergy for the professional staff

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergy alert bracelets utilize the HFE strategy of visual reminders, which are most effective when located near the relevant action. Since inpatient orders are often entered away from the bedside, allergy alert bracelets have limited effectiveness in preventing prescribing errors and are more effective in preventing medication administration errors. Moreover, visual reminders by themselves are weak interventions on the action hierarchy of HFE because of susceptibility to attentional capture and alert fatigue.

B) INCORRECT:

Bar code technology that links a patient with their prescribed medication can prevent medication administration errors. The system can also be designed to act as a final defense against the downstream effects of prescribing errors (based on the Swiss cheese model). For example, barcode technology can generate an alert if the patient's medication allergy is digitally recorded and the provider scans the barcode before administering the medication. However, the system cannot prevent prescribing errors themselves and is still vulnerable to workarounds (e.g., providers not scanning barcodes) and the effects of alert fatigue (e.g., providers ignoring the alerts).

C) INCORRECT:

Although pharmacist participation during rounds can help educate prescribers and reduce adverse events from medication interactions, it would not have prevented the error in this scenario because this error occurred before formal rounds.

D) CORRECT:

The development of computerized provider order entry systems with decision support, including allergy alerts, is particularly effective in reducing drug allergies due to prescribing errors. However, not all alerts have equal clinical significance, and a high frequency of alerts can lead to alert fatigue. One practical strategy is to use a tiered approach to applying alerts instead of using them for all possible oversights or errors in ordering. With this approach, a small subset of very dangerous clinical situations would generate alerts that either demand a response from the ordering clinician or, in a few select cases, even force a change to the intended order, with a reduction in the risk of clinician override.

E) INCORRECT:

Education of health care providers by itself is generally a weak intervention on the action hierarchy of HFE to reduce errors. Most errors by health care providers are not the result of medical knowledge deficit (nescient error).
questions.hint: Medication errors can occur at the stages of prescribing, transcribing, dispensing, or administration. The medication error that occurred in this scenario is a prescribing error (ordering error). The nurse noticed the error and was able to prevent a potentially serious adverse effect, which makes this error a near-miss event. The underlying cause of alert fatigue can be addressed by a specific human factors engineering (HFE) approach.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and chronic renal insufficiency is being discharged after hospitalization for an exacerbation of heart failure. His presenting symptoms of orthopnea and peripheral edema have responded well to several days of diuretic therapy. A previous echocardiogram, performed when the patient was euvolemic, showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%. The patient's medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, carvedilol, spironolactone, and furosemide. He lives with his son and has adequate financial support. His son has agreed to obtain a pill box from the pharmacy and to monitor his father's medication and dietary adherence. Which of the following steps before discharge would most effectively reduce this patients risk of readmission?

choices.text: Arrange a follow-up appointment with the primary care provider
Write the discharge summary in simple jargon-free language
Link inpatient and outpatient medications electronically
Provide the patient a phone number to call in case of difficulties

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Readmissions can be reduced effectively by focusing on several areas of the discharge process. Before discharge, a follow-up appointment should be arranged with the patient's primary care provider. Simply alerting the patients primary care provider about discharge is not as effective as actually ensuring that the patient has appropriate follow-up appointments in place. In addition, a specific staff member should be assigned the responsibility of performing medication reconciliation, education on medication use, and follow-up on laboratory results that are still pending. Within 23 days of discharge, an electronic discharge summary should be sent to the patients primary care provider and a postdischarge follow-up phone call should happen. This phone call supports continuity of care until the patient's appointment with their primary care provider and helps address issues during this period that may increase the risk of readmission. A visiting nurse program offering skilled services (e.g., physical therapy, medication management) through home visits can also help reduce the risk of readmission. Patients qualify for Medicare-covered visiting nurse services if they meet the homebound criteria, i.e., requiring assistance from both another person and a device to leave their home.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharge summaries include a section that provides patient instructions and plans for follow-up care in easy-to-understand language. Although such a step improves the patient's understanding, it is not the most effective measure to help the patient navigate the complexities of the healthcare system and receive adequate management after discharge. Additionally, the discharge summary is also intended to inform the patient's primary care provider, so writing the entire discharge summary in jargon-free language may not be feasible.

C) INCORRECT:

Medication reconciliation, a key part of the discharge process, can help decrease the risk of readmissions. Linking an individual's inpatient and outpatient medications through an integrated electronic health record system can make medication reconciliation easier but this intervention does not by itself complete the medication reconciliation process.

D) INCORRECT:

Discharge summaries include contact information of the attending physician and consulting services involved in the patient's care to allow the patient or their primary health care provider to reach out in case of postdischarge care difficulties. However, patients may be hesitant to initiate contact, and relying on this passive system places the responsibility for follow-up on the patient. Instead, actively calling the patient at home about postdischarge needs within 23 days of discharge is part of effective discharge programs.
questions.hint: Common causes for hospital readmission include complications or exacerbations of existing health conditions, inadequate management after discharge, and posthospital syndrome. Patients with advanced heart failure have some of the highest rates of hospital readmission.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital because of difficulty breathing, increasing dyspnea on exertion, a productive cough, and wheezing. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and continues to smoke actively. Following evaluation, she is referred for bronchoscopy. Immediately after the procedure, the bronchoscopist is called to the emergency department and has to leave the bronchoscopy unit. When the patient is brought back to her room, she reports mild dyspnea and is treated with nebulized albuterol. Two hours after the bronchoscopy, she develops respiratory distress and quickly becomes hypotensive and unresponsive. She improves only after needle decompression to treat what is eventually recognized as a pneumothorax. After further review of the patients records, it was discovered that an unplanned transbronchial biopsy was performed. Which of the following strategies would most effectively have prevented the error that occurred in this scenario?

choices.text: Implementation of routine post-bronchoscopy monitoring with continuous pulse oximetry
Holding a continued medical education seminar on post-bronchoscopy care
Introduction of a process improvement measure to ensure routine post-bronchoscopy chest radiography
Use of a structured template for the handover after bronchoscopy
Use of a checklist to ensure measurement of vital signs on an hourly basis after bronchoscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Post-bronchoscopy monitoring with continuous pulse oximetry would not have allowed for early detection of the pneumothorax. A small pneumothorax does not cause hypoxemia unless the patient has a pre-existing lung disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Although a seminar about post-bronchoscopy care could have been helpful, it is unlikely to have been useful if the team was not aware that a transbronchial biopsy was performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine post-bronchoscopy chest radiography represents an inappropriate use of resources and is not routinely recommended. Obtaining a chest radiograph after every bronchoscopy is not indicated because the risk of pneumothorax is almost negligible in patients undergoing simple inspection or lavage. In many institutions, a chest radiograph is obtained after transbronchial biopsies, but even this practice has been brought into question by recent evidence.

D) CORRECT:

The risk of transition of care errors can be significantly decreased by an effective handover. The most effective patient handovers occur in a structured format using templates, tools, and checklists (e.g., SBAR, IPASS), so that all necessary information is communicated. Most handover tools include a patient summary, information on illness severity, action items, and contingency planning. A read-back by the receiver improves the quality of the handover. These approaches to interprofessional communication are associated with reduced rates of adverse events and are widely recommended. In this particular case, a more complete handover with an inclusion of the biopsy would have allowed the responding clinicians to recognize the cause of mild dyspnea more quickly with frequent focused physical examinations or a chest x-ray, and address the condition early on. Appropriate treatment for the pneumothorax (chest tube placement) could have been performed before the patient decompensated.

E) INCORRECT:

The care providers must be informed that a transbronchial biopsy was performed because this information improves their situational awareness and helps them recognize and respond to a pneumothorax faster than if they were only measuring vital signs at specific intervals. Checklists are useful for ensuring all necessary steps are taken during a transition of care process, but checklists are by themselves not a cure-all and may not be effective if standard safety practices are not already established.
questions.hint: The risk of pneumothorax is almost negligible in patients undergoing bronchoscopy with simple inspection or lavage, but there is a significantly higher risk of post-procedural pneumothorax when a transbronchial biopsy is performed. Early recognition of a condition requires situational awareness of the patient's risk for the condition. Certain transitions in care, including those that occur after procedures, are particularly risky.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with moderate persistent asthma and seasonal allergies is brought to the emergency department for treatment of an asthma exacerbation. The patient receives albuterol, ipratropium, and a 40 mg (2 mg/kg) loading dose of oral prednisolone in the emergency department. The patient is admitted and his weight of 20 kg (44 lb) is recorded in the electronic health record. The admitting clinician places an order for 40 mg of oral prednisolone every 12 hours instead of the correct maintenance dose of 10 mg (0.5 mg/kg) every 12 hours. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate to prevent the type of medication error that occurred in this scenario?

choices.text: Standardizing dose calculation based on body surface area rather than body weight
Placing standing orders in the emergency department before the patient is admitted
Integrating dose-range checking in the order entry system
Tall-man lettering of prednisone and prednisolone in the hospital formulary

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The calculation of medication dosage based on body surface area (BSA) is only necessary for certain medications (e.g., chemotherapeutic drugs). For most medications, including corticosteroids, dosage is determined based on the patients age or weight, rather than BSA. Implementing BSA-based dosing for all medications would needlessly complicate dosage calculations without addressing the primary cause of dosing errors in this scenario.

B) INCORRECT:

Standing orders are pre-approved protocols that authorize nurses and physician assistants to perform specific medical tasks without a direct physician's order. They are not appropriate as admitting orders when transferring patients with complex or unstable conditions (e.g., acute asthma exacerbation) from the emergency department to an inpatient care unit.

C) CORRECT:

Dosing challenges specific to children include weight-based dosing and dosing with age restrictions. With the switch to electronic medical records (EHRs), pediatric dosing errors can be significantly decreased by integrating dose-range checking with a computerized order entry system. Such a system automatically compares the prescribed dose to the recommended range based on the indication and the patients weight and age entered in the EHR. If the dose is outside the safe range, the system alerts the prescriber to review and adjust the order.

Other strategies to prevent pediatric dosing errors include weighing the patient at admission (or within 4 hours if the patient was admitted in a critical condition) and recording the weight in kilograms rather than pounds. The prescribing physician should include both the calculated dose and the weight-specific dosing in medication orders to allow for independent double-checks. Whenever possible, the use of pediatric-specific formulations is recommended. Clear labeling and physical separation of pediatric formulations from adult medications in storage areas can help prevent mix-ups. For oral liquid medications, oral syringes of the appropriate size should be used to ensure accurate dosing.

D) INCORRECT:

Tall-man lettering is used to differentiate look-alike, sound-alike (LASA) medications (e.g., predniSONE vs. predniSOLONE) and prevent drug selection errors. However, in this case, the dosage error was due to entering the wrong dose, not the wrong drug. Also, since prednisone and prednisolone have equivalent dosages, it is unlikely that the dosing error was caused by the clinician looking up the dose of prednisone instead of prednisolone in the hospital formulary.
questions.hint: A prescribing error occurs when a physician orders an inappropriate medication or the correct medication with an incorrect dosage. Prescribing errors occur about three times more often in pediatric patients than in adult patients. Studies show that dosing miscalculations are one of the most common medication safety problems in children.

questions.text: A 16-month-old girl is brought to the clinic by her mother for a follow-up visit. Ten days ago, the patient was diagnosed with acute otitis media in the right ear and prescribed an oral liquid formulation of amoxicillin. The mother does not speak English and a Spanish interpreter is used to facilitate communication. During this visit, the mother reports that the child remains irritable. Examination of the right ear discloses persistent otitis media. With the assistance of the interpreter, it is revealed that the mother has been inadvertently administering 5 mL of the liquid formulation per dose instead of the prescribed 10 mL. She has been using a kitchen teaspoon to administer the medication. Which of the following interventions at this visit is most likely to prevent the type of medication error that occurred in this scenario from recurring?

choices.text: Have the pharmacy dispense extra medication to compensate for any loss due to spitting or spillage
Teach and then ask the mother to demonstrate the proper method to measure the medication
Instruct the mother to buy a kitchen tablespoon and limit its use to medication administration
Have the pharmacy dispense a plastic dosing cup for administering oral liquid formulations
Provide written instructions in Spanish on correct dosing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although infants often spit back some of their medication, providing an oversupply of medication does not prevent medication administration errors.

B) CORRECT:

Counseling strategies to improve how providers communicate medication instructions to parents include the use of pictures or drawings, and provider demonstration followed by a "teach back" or "show back." Demonstrating the correct way to administer a liquid medication using the proper dosing tool, and then asking the caregiver to "show back" the technique is an effective strategy to ensure they understand the proper dosing. People also tend to remember the steps of a process more when they have had to physically demonstrate the process than when they have simply read or heard the steps. Appropriate dosing tools for administering oral liquid formulations to children include oral syringes, dosing spoons, and droppers. The use of dosing cups is associated with a higher error rate, and kitchen spoons should not be used to administer medications because their size is not standardized.

C) INCORRECT:

Kitchen spoons should not be used to administer medications because their size is not standardized.

D) INCORRECT:

For oral liquid medications, the use of dosing cups is associated with a higher error rate than the use of oral syringes, dosing spoons, or droppers. Moreover, simply having the pharmacy dispense a dosing cup may not lead to the correct dosing of medication if this step is not connected with strategies to assess understanding.

E) INCORRECT:

Although written instructions in Spanish may be helpful, they are not the most effective measure to ensure that the patient has understood the correct way to administer the oral liquid formulation.
questions.hint: The type of medication error that occurred in this scenario is a medication administration error. More than 40% of caregivers make errors in dosing when administering oral liquid medications.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman develops chills and right flank pain while awaiting an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. She was admitted to the hospital with hematemesis and received one unit of packed red blood cells 30 minutes ago. The patient has no history of previous transfusions. Her temperature is 39.2째C (102.6째F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows right costovertebral angle tenderness. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
8.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7500/mm3



Platelet count
180,000/mm3



Serum



 Total bilirubin
4.0 mg/dL


 Lactate dehydrogenase

700 U/L


A direct antiglobulin test (Coombs test) is positive. The transfusion is stopped, and the blood bank is notified of a suspected transfusion reaction. A debriefing and clinical peer review with the medical team and blood bank personnel is convened following the incident. Which of the following measures should be emphasized during this meeting to prevent the type of transfusion-related complication that occurred in this scenario?

choices.text: Use of a computerized system to track and screen blood donors
Checking at least two patient identifiers before administering a transfusion
Maintaining cold chain storage while the blood product is in transit from the blood bank
Storing packed red cell products in the blood bank only after they have been washed
Use of an infusion pump with a preset maximum flow rate during transfusion

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Computerized systems for tracking and screening blood donors can prevent the transmission of infectious diseases and identify blood products that are associated with a high risk of certain complications (e.g., transfusion-related acute lung injury with blood products from multiparous donors). However, such a system is not effective in preventing AHTRs. The errors that lead to AHTRs typically occur during recipient identification, sample collection, labeling, or administration, rather than in the donor screening process.

B) CORRECT:

An ABO-incompatible transfusion, which is the most likely cause of this patient's immune AHTR, is a never event. The transfusion process includes several steps such as identifying the patients blood group, placing the order, identifying a matched blood product, labeling and dispensing the blood product, and administering the product to the correct patient. Errors can occur at any stage of this process but the most common causes of ABO-incompatible transfusions are blood product administration errors and wrong blood in tube (WBIT) errors. A strategy of conducting two determinations of the patients ABO group (e.g., by testing a second sample) can reduce the risk of misidentification during pretransfusion testing and mitigate the impact of WBIT errors. Not all patients know and recall their blood group accurately, so a self-reported blood group is not reliable. Blood product administration errors, such as transfusing an RBC unit to the wrong patient, account for about one-third of cases and can be prevented through final bedside verification of the patients identity against the transfusion order and blood product. Before every transfusion, this should be done using at least two identifiers (e.g., name, date of birth). Limiting the blood transfusion process to a single provider, from the initial order to the moment of transfusion, may minimize mistakes associated with handoffs.

C) INCORRECT:

Maintaining proper cold chain storage is crucial for ensuring the viability and safety of certain blood products (e.g., packed red blood cells). However, this measure primarily aims to prevent transfusion-related sepsis caused by the growth of pathogens in blood products. Non-immune AHTRs due to thermal damage to erythrocytes are rare and unlikely in this patient, who has a positive direct antiglobulin test, indicating an immune-mediated mechanism.

D) INCORRECT:

Routine washing of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) is not recommended as it reduces shelf life and is costly. It is only considered in specific situations, such as when there is a risk of anaphylactic reactions to transfusions (e.g., IgA-depleted blood products for patients with selective IgA deficiency). This case involves an immune AHTR, which is a type II hypersensitivity reaction, not anaphylaxis. While washing reduces donor anti-A and anti-B antibody levels in the blood product, immune AHTRs are primarily caused by recipient antibodies. Donor antibodies only become relevant as a cause of AHTR when large volumes of ABO-incompatible plasma are transfused, not with a single pRBC transfusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Slowing the rate of transfusion helps to prevent transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which typically occurs during or within 12 hours of transfusion. However, TACO is associated with findings of hypervolemia (e.g., pulmonary edema, jugular venous distention), not hypovolemia. AHTR cannot be effectively prevented by limiting the transfusion rate.
questions.hint: Fever, chills, costovertebral angle tenderness, hypotension, and hemolysis occurring immediately after transfusion are consistent with an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR). The positive direct antiglobulin test indicates an immune-mediated mechanism, and the absence of a prior transfusion history makes non-ABO-related immune AHTR unlikely.

questions.text: Two days after admission to the hospital for treatment of pneumonia, a 78-year-old woman undergoes a CT scan of the abdomen instead of the chest. The clinician realizes the error, informs the patient, and reports it to the hospital's event reporting system. Since the hospital was opened 1 year ago, the hospital management has received several reports of clinicians inadvertently overlooking important clinical information in patient records, clinical deterioration of admitted patients following missed changes in vital signs, laboratory test results being issued for wrong patients, and patients accidentally receiving incorrect drug doses. An insurance company had also recently accused the hospital of billing for services that were never performed. A root cause analysis is most likely to reveal which of the following as the common source of these errors?

choices.text: Medical knowledge deficits among frontline staff
Blame culture at the workplace
Misconduct by a hospital administrator
Value-based care reimbursement model
Copy functionality in documentation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Medical knowledge deficits among health care providers (HCPs) can lead to nescient errors in diagnosis and treatment, in which HCPs overlook relevant symptoms and examination findings. However, incorrect dose prescriptions and patient misidentification by HCPs are more likely to be caused by slips and lapses (types of skill-based error) than by nescient errors.

B) INCORRECT:

Blame culture refers to a situation in which health care employees are reluctant to report errors due to fear of prosecution or criticism. In this case, the clinician openly disclosed the error to the patient and via the hospital's event reporting system, so there is no evidence of blame culture or a lack of psychological safety at the hospital.

C) INCORRECT:

Misconduct by a hospital administrator (e.g., the hospital's accountant) could explain the insurance company's accusations of potential insurance fraud. However, the multiple adverse events described here were most likely made by multiple staff members (i.e., clinicians, nurses) and therefore can not be attributed to a single hospital administrator.

D) INCORRECT:

Value-based care (i.e. pay for performance) is a payment model in which compensation depends on health care providers meeting certain metrics for the quality and efficiency of care provided. This payment model typically promotes coordination and quality of care through financial incentives, which is why it is unlikely to be responsible for the multiple adverse events at this organization. Fee-for-service reimbursement models, on the other hand, typically lead to healthcare fragmentation and may thereby increase the incidence of medical errors and lead to unnecessary repetition of services.

E) CORRECT:

Documentation errors caused by copying and pasting information in electronic health records (EHRs) are the most likely common source of the medical errors described here. EHRs, which were increasingly adopted following the HITECH Act of 2009, have several advantages (e.g., transparency, high fidelity) but also create the possibility for certain errors. The copy/paste function may result in the entry of incorrect or outdated information or the entry of information into the wrong patient's EHR, and subsequently lead to errors such as incorrect drug dosing, performing tests or treatment on the wrong patient, and billing for services that were never performed. Duplicating information also promotes note bloat, the proliferation of lengthy notes that include redundant, nonessential information, which may lead to clinicians overlooking important facts. The unchecked transfer of outdated patient data, such as previous vital signs, can lead to the deterioration of patients due to missed changes in their condition.

Forcing functions on workstations such as allowing only one EHR to be open at a time, clipboard clearing, and disabling copy/paste functionality in certain parts of the EHR can prevent these errors. Other measures to improve safety with EHR use include the implementation of standardized protocols (e.g., SAFER guide) and personnel training.
questions.hint: All the medical errors described here are related to a particular workaround in one of the hospital's management systems.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of ischemic cardiomyopathy and chronic renal insufficiency is being discharged after hospitalization for an exacerbation of heart failure. A previous echocardiogram, performed when the patient was euvolemic, showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 25%. The patient's medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, lisinopril, carvedilol, spironolactone, and furosemide. He lives with his son and has adequate financial support. His son has agreed to obtain a pill box from the pharmacy and to monitor his father's medication and dietary adherence. Which of the following steps before discharge would most effectively reduce this patients risk of readmission?

choices.text: Write the discharge summary in simple jargon-free language
Provide the patient a phone number to call in case of difficulties
Link inpatient and outpatient medications electronically
Arrange a follow-up appointment with the primary care provider

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge summaries include a section that provides patient instructions and plans for follow-up care in easy-to-understand language. Although such a step improves the patient's understanding, it is not the most effective measure to help the patient navigate the complexities of the healthcare system and receive adequate management after discharge. Additionally, the discharge summary is also intended to inform the patient's primary care provider, so writing the entire discharge summary in jargon-free language may not be feasible.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharge summaries include contact information of the attending physician and consulting services involved in the patient's care to allow the patient or their primary health care provider to reach out in case of postdischarge care difficulties. However, patients may be hesitant to initiate contact, and relying on this passive system places the responsibility for follow-up on the patient. Instead, actively calling the patient at home about postdischarge needs within 23 days of discharge is part of effective discharge programs.

C) INCORRECT:

Medication reconciliation, a key part of the discharge process, can help decrease the risk of readmissions. Linking an individual's inpatient and outpatient medications through an integrated electronic health record system can make medication reconciliation easier but this intervention does not by itself complete the medication reconciliation process.

D) CORRECT:

Readmissions can be reduced effectively by focusing on several areas of the discharge process. Before discharge, a follow-up appointment should be arranged with the patient's primary care provider. Simply alerting the patients primary care provider about discharge is not as effective as actually ensuring that the patient has appropriate follow-up appointments in place. In addition, a specific staff member should be assigned the responsibility of performing medication reconciliation, education on medication use, and follow-up on laboratory results that are still pending. Within 23 days of discharge, an electronic discharge summary should be sent to the patients primary care provider and a postdischarge follow-up phone call should happen. This phone call supports continuity of care until the patient's appointment with their primary care provider and helps address issues during this period that may increase the risk of readmission.
