choices.text: "I believe you accidentally put on the wrong gloves."
I suggest we perform a root cause analysis to make sure this error does not happen again.
I am really sorry, but I have to report your mistake to the head nurse to ensure transparent communication.
Lets go over everything again to make sure we did not forget something before we insert the catheter."
Do you need any help with the insertion of the catheter?

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Whenever a person witnesses a medical error, they should directly inform the health care provider who committed the error. This should be done politely and without regard for workplace hierarchy, interpersonal relationships, or the potential of a career setback. A witness who fails to act is also culpable for the consequences of the error. Early medical error reporting can offer a chance for rectification (e.g., replacing nonsterile gloves with sterile gloves) and prevent a near miss (e.g., break of sterile technique) from becoming an adverse event (e.g., catheter-associated urinary tract infection). Patient safety (nonmaleficence) is the foremost priority; a safety culture fosters the reporting of both active errors (as seen here) and latent errors.

B) INCORRECT:

Analysis of medical errors (e.g., root cause analysis) is in line with good safety culture and necessary to prevent future errors. However, a root cause analysis is performed after a procedure has been completed. Another reaction is more appropriate at this point in time.

C) INCORRECT:

It is necessary to report of medical errors (e.g., through an incident reporting system), and doing so is in line with good safety culture. However, reporting the error to the head nurse at this step in the procedure delays the possibility of rectifying the error and increases the risk that a near miss (e.g., break in sterile technique) becomes an adverse event (e.g., catheter-associated urinary tract infection). Furthermore, it is the responsibility of the person who committed the error to report it. It would be more appropriate for the student to give the nurse the chance to self report the error at a later time.

D) INCORRECT:

This statement does not directly address the problem that sterile technique has not been followed, which may convey the assumption that the procedure has not been compromised. Whenever a medical error is witnessed, the witness of the error should speak up. Addressing the error immediately makes rectification possible.

E) INCORRECT:

Collaboration across teams is necessary, and it is generally appropriate for the student to offer to help the nurse. However, urinary catheter insertion should be performed using sterile technique, which includes wearing sterile gloves. This nurse just put on nonsterile gloves. Any break in sterile technique jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error. Another reaction is more appropriate at this stage of the procedure.
questions.hint: Urinary catheter insertion is an aseptic procedure. Sterile technique, including wearing sterile gloves, should be maintained. Any break in the sterile field jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department of a busy suburban hospital because of a 1-week history of nausea and vomiting. She also has had intermittent fevers and headaches during the past 5 weeks. She does not have a stiff neck or sensitivity to light. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37.0째C (98.6째F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. She is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows no abnormalities. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is collected for analysis. On the way to the laboratory, the clinician loses the CSF specimens. The clinician decides that a repeat lumbar puncture should be performed. Before giving consent for the second procedure, the patient asks what the results are from the specimens obtained earlier. Which of the following responses is the most appropriate?

choices.text: "I sincerely apologize; I misplaced the specimens. Thankfully, this is not a big issue because I can easily obtain more fluid."
"I was unable to obtain results from the earlier tests because I misplaced the specimens. I sincerely apologize for the mistake."
"I was not able to get the answers we needed from the first set of tests, so we need to repeat them."
"Unfortunately, I was not able to get enough fluid in the specimens to perform the tests."
"I sincerely apologize; the lab seems to have lost the specimens I obtained earlier."
"There were just too many patients for us to keep track of today. I am so sorry, but I misplaced the specimens."
"Based on your symptoms, I think you might have chronic meningitis."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the clinician lost the specimens, it is inappropriate because it minimizes the gravity of the situation. Clinicians should disclose errors in objective terms and refrain from placing a value judgment on the significance of the error because each patient will have a unique response.

B) CORRECT:

This response is the most appropriate way of disclosing the medical error to the patient. Disclosure of medical errors involves clearly admitting the error, describing the nature of the error, and expressing personal regret or apology. Timely, full disclosure of errors is beneficial for the healthcare professional-patient relationship and patient safety.

C) INCORRECT:

This response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred. In addition, it may mislead the patient into believing that the tests were performed but inconclusive.

D) INCORRECT:

This response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred. In addition, it falsely claims that the CSF collected from the first lumbar puncture was inadequate.

E) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the specimens were lost, it is inappropriate because it falsely blames the laboratory. Optimal error disclosure involves clearly admitting that an error has occurred and truthfully stating the course of events that led to the error.

F) INCORRECT:

Although this response does disclose that the clinician lost the specimens, it is inappropriate because it makes an unprofessional excuse and implies that the error was unavoidable.

G) INCORRECT:

Although the patient's subacute development of nausea, vomiting, headache, and fevers is concerning for a diagnosis of chronic meningitis, this response is inappropriate because it fails to disclose that a medical error has occurred.
questions.hint: The loss of the first CSF specimens constitutes a medical error.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She was an unrestrained driver. She appears lethargic. Her temperature is 36.6째C (97.8째F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg. A Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma scan of the abdomen shows free intraabdominal fluid, and the patient is taken to the operating room for an emergent laparotomy. A physician associate student, who is attempting to get a letter of recommendation from the head surgeon, joins the surgery. After the abdominal cavity is opened, marked hemorrhaging is seen, reducing visibility of the area. While the head surgeon uses sterile towels to clean the abdominal cavity and increase the visibility of the area, the student notices that the head surgeon's left hand drops below the height of the table after discarding a bloody sterile towel. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the student?

choices.text: Inform the patient after the surgery
Ask the head surgeon after the surgery if sterility was broken
Inform the operating room nurse immediately about the incident
Pull the head surgeon immediately away from the operating field
Inform the head surgeon immediately about the incident

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Whenever a medical error occurs, the person who committed the error must inform the patient, even if the error were a near miss. Therefore, the head surgeon, rather than the student, should report the error to the patient. Furthermore, the most appropriate initial action by the student, in this case, should take place immediately and not after the surgery in order to ensure patient safety.

B) INCORRECT:

If the student is concerned that surgical sterility was broken, it would not be appropriate to wait until after surgery to rectify the situation. Right now, the medical error is a near miss because the surgeon's hand has dropped below the table but has not yet reentered the operating field; if the surgeon continues to perform the procedure, the patient will have an increased risk of developing a surgical site infection (an adverse event).

C) INCORRECT:

With this action, the student places the responsibility of error reporting on the operating room nurse, who might not have witnessed the event and would have to act based on hearsay. The nurse might also choose to remain silent to avoid a confrontation with the head surgeon. Even if the nurse decides to inform the surgeon, using an intermediary in communicating with the head surgeon would delay rectifying the error and potentially convert a near miss into an adverse event (surgical site infection).

D) INCORRECT:

This action jeopardizes both the surgeon's and patient's safety by increasing the risk of a surgical mishap (e.g., scalpel injury) and could constitute assault.

E) CORRECT:

Whenever a medical error is witnessed, as is the case here, the person who witnessed the error should speak up and directly inform the health care provider who committed the error without any regard for the workplace hierarchy, interpersonal relationships, or the potential of a career setback. The witness who fails to act is also culpable for the consequences of the error. Early medical error reporting might offer a chance for rectification (e.g., rescrubbing) and prevent a near miss (e.g., nonadherence with the sterile protocol) from becoming an adverse event (e.g., surgical site infection). Patient safety (nonmaleficence) is the foremost priority; a safety culture fosters the reporting of both active errors, as seen here, and latent errors. The health care provider who commits a medical error should report the error to the patient, regardless of the outcome of the error, as well as to the hospital board via an incident reporting system.
questions.hint: During surgery, scrubbed personnel breach the surgical field if they raise their hand(s) above head height or lower their hand(s) below table height, even if there is no obvious contact with a nonsterile surface. Any break in procedural sterility jeopardizes patient safety and constitutes a medical error.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy was admitted for pneumonia and started on intravenous antibiotics. The next morning, he developed a severe rash and required additional supportive measures. His mother questions whether a nurse forgot to ask about allergies. She is upset and wants to know what happened and how it can be prevented in the future. The physician meets with the family. What is the most appropriate approach to address her concerns?

choices.text: Downplay the severity of the rash, stating that such reactions are an accepted risk of treatment
Suggest the mother pursue legal counsel if she is dissatisfied with her son's care
Redirect the mother to the nursing staff, emphasizing their responsibility for medication checks
Offer a sincere apology, acknowledge the complication, and reassure that a thorough investigation will be conducted

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Downplaying the severity of a severe rash requiring additional measures fails to acknowledge the family's distress and undermines transparent communication. It dismisses the seriousness of the adverse event and may lead to a loss of trust. Acknowledging the family's concerns and outlining preventive measures are essential for patient-centered care.

B) INCORRECT:

Suggesting legal counsel introduces an adversarial element and detracts from the clinical responsibility to engage transparently with the family. The focus should be on explaining the event, disclosing errors, and outlining corrective actions, rather than diverting the conversation toward litigation.

C) INCORRECT:

Redirecting the family to the nursing staff deflects accountability from the physician and risks undermining trust. The entire healthcare team is accountable for adverse events, and the physician should coordinate a transparent discussion. Isolating blame on one discipline ignores systemic issues and fails to address the family's concerns about prevention and safety.

D) CORRECT:

Effective communication after an adverse event involves transparency, accountability, and empathy. Offering a sincere apology and acknowledging the complication validates the family's concerns and establishes an honest dialogue. Committing to a thorough investigation demonstrates adherence to ethical standards and patient safety protocols. This approach builds trust by addressing the event and outlining steps for quality improvement, aligning with healthcare communication practices that emphasize open disclosure about errors.

Key learning point: In cases of medical errors or complications, it is important to apologize, acknowledge the situation, and reassure the family that an investigation will be conducted to prevent future occurrences.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of fever and productive cough for 4 days. He has a known allergy to penicillins. Physical examination shows crackles over the right lung base. An x-ray of the chest shows a left lower lobe infiltrate. He receives treatment with ampicillin and sulbactam. Shortly after administration of the antibiotic, the patient develops shortness of breath, hives, and angioedema. After he has been medically stabilized, the patient asks if the event is related to his treatment in the hospital. Which of the following responses by the clinician is the most appropriate?

choices.text: "Unfortunately, we did not know about your allergy. You should make sure to wear an allergy awareness bracelet at all times."
"You have experienced an adverse drug reaction, which is very common with the use of this medication."
"Yes, your symptoms are most likely due to an allergic reaction caused by the administration of antibiotics. I sincerely apologize for the mistake."
"Yes, you have experienced an allergic reaction. The nurse that gave you this medication should have asked you whether you have any allergies."
"At this point, we don't know for sure whether the medication has caused your symptoms. It could have been anything."

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This response implies that the patient's symptoms may have resulted from an allergy, but it does not clearly disclose the cause of the patient's adverse event, nor that the allergic reaction resulted from a medical error. It also incorrectly places blame on the patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Clinicians must inform the patient immediately if an error has occurred, regardless of the treatment outcome. However, this response is vague and does not disclose that the allergic reaction resulted from a medical error.

C) CORRECT:

Regardless of the outcome of a treatment, a clinician must inform the patient immediately if an error has occurred and disclose the nature of that error. Full disclosure of errors to a patient provides information needed for the patient to make informed decisions about the management of their health. In addition to disclosing an error, the clinician should apologize for the mistake.

D) INCORRECT:

This response admits that an error has occurred, but it inappropriately shifts the blame to another healthcare worker.

E) INCORRECT:

This response fails to disclose the cause of the patient's adverse event and that the event resulted from a medical error. It is dishonest; a different approach is more appropriate.
questions.hint: The administration of an inappropriate drug is one of the most common types of medical errors. In this case, it led to a severe adverse drug reaction.
